Zombies have been a staple in all sorts of media throughout the west. When it comes to anime zombies aren't exactly Unheard of but still are fairly prevalent within the medium. An example of this would be High School of the dead or the manga I am a hero. However today I am talking about an anime that comes from a studio that has produced a famous anime you've probably heard of, and that anime is attack on Titan. 
 Kabaneri of the iron fortress is a twelve episode anime series that debuted in the spring 2016 season. Kabaneri stood out from other titlesdue to its steampunk setting and stunning animation quality. However it was met with widespread criticism as the series progressed into the second half and went from an 8.3 on MAL to about a 7.6. This is a significant drop in such a short timeframe. While I see some people giving it very low scores I weighted my enjoyment and the actual quality of the anime together into one score. 


The story of kabaneri takes place in a island country very similar to Japan that is suffering from a zombie apocalypse. Then there is this basic protagonist who is trying to develop a way to kill the zombies also known as kabane. He than meets several other characters and it follows them as they try to survive.


The story wasn't that bad at first. It starts out as a pretty linear survival action story with some good entertainment value. However during the second half what happens is, is that a new character gets introduced and than the story becomes much more convoluted and confusing. Than the story ends up losing all of its charm and becomes very confusing for the viewer to experience. It kind of strays away from that fun mindless popcorn flick and just becomes something that's way too complex for its own good. However there is some kick ass action scenes in this anime which is amplified by a great musical score and amazing animation. Another great thing was the actual kabane concept because it was different from other zombies throughout media. Despite this taking place in Japan, there was some great world building present throughout the anime using industrial revolution and the stations.


People always say that good characters can save a mediocre story and for the most part I really do agree with  this concept. However what really makes this anime just ok is the characters. With good characters this anime could have merited a much higher score. However all of them were just so bland and lifeless.


Ikoma is the standard vengeful angry MC who is looking for revenge. He also has a very cliched back story that we've seen in many other characters. He also suffers from the half breed cliche because the story decided to make him a half zombie( LIKE WE HAVENT SEEN THAT ONE BEFORE.) Mumei is a Loli half zombie who has a cool design but seems to be a generic tsundere. However she had a good relationship with Ikoma and Biba. You have princess Ayama who isn't really developed that well. Kurusu has a cool design but no development or back story. And the list goes on. We needed more characterization to make these characters more relatable. Biba was a decent villain despite being bland, he had good motivation though.


The three greatest parts of this anime were the art,music, and action. The action in this anime was actually really good with great fluidity and it works with the zombie concept. The art was lovely with some great lighting and polish. There was also some great color thrown in as well. The music was epic with some great voice work and epic tunes that worked in various scenes. 


 In conclusion Iron fortress was kind of a let down. It serves well as a popcorn flick you can watch with your friends but it soon dissolves into overblown convoluted concepts. This takes the charm away. However this is worth watching if you like zombies and action but don't expect too much out of it.

Real life logic does not always apply to an anime series. Fictional universes have a set of made up laws and axioms that should be consistent with a fictional work's story. Logic can still be used on fictional works as long as the rules stipulated are consistent and the logic is based on those very rules. When something happens that seemingly contradicts what has been established it can be very jarring for many people and at this point the best thing to do is to throw said logic out the window. I love the art-style and animation of this anime. This anime was very funand enjoyable for me and as an action anime it excels, but be warned to fully enjoy this anime you must suspend disbelief. Watch this anime for its amazing sound track and action.

TLDR; Its a fun show, its cheesy and derpy and has some pretty blatant flaws, but if you just want a fun actiony show to watch then its pretty ok.
This show hooked me. It had a pretty strong opening few episodes in my opinion. Once you get deeper into the show though it becomes a little repetitive and predictable.
On r/anime they pointed out some really glaring flaws that I thought I should mention. Sometimes the zombies show up out of no where and sometimes people do things completely out of character.
The story isn't really worth it. Generic apocalypse shit with some weird theme. Instead ofwalls (like in attack on titan) its trains.


The art is alright and animation isn't bad. It was consistent throughout the season, unlike Tokyo Ghoul Season 2 which had some very clear budget drops at  certain scenes. 


The sound and music are the best part of the show. They had a very satisfying kill noise, and the music was very good in my opinion. I didn't watch very many other shows this season so far so I can't compare, but the OP and ED are very good. The dialogue is also pretty clear and concise. The second to last episode ends on a very cool song too.


Characters are bland and boring. The MC becomes this badass hybrid human zombie thing, but he doesn't do anything nearly as cool as his female MC counterpart. Nobody develops and some people are annoying. The MC is not a little crybaby though (for the most part) so that is a plus.


I got what I wanted out of this show. It was a cool, weird themed show that kept me wanting to see what happened next, even if it was predictable.


Overall it is NOT a MUST watch, but if you're open and don't know what else to watch this should be able to hold you over and give you little laugh and a smile, and maybe even a little hype.


Hope this helped!

May seem like the typical tween who posts a 10/10 review, but I have to give this one a 10/10.
I heard about it but wasn't too sure, as I'd need to watch it subbed. Even though I did, it captured my attention and made me think or try to interpret things with a friend I watched it with. We watched it as each episode came out and as it drew on and captivated us, we would become so annoyed when it ended because we wanted more. Hoping more is to come, this one was a really awesome series.
I feel like it ended on a cliffhanger,which just frustrates me but makes me want to see more. I usually am not for Steam Punk-esque things, but this one I'll gladly make an exception for. It might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I sure loved it.

Do you like trains, zombie monsters, dastardly evil doers that just want to kill anyone they deem unworthy, and steampunk.  If you answered yes to any or all of these then Koutetsujou no Kabaneri is the anime for you! 
Story: 
The story goes as follows: Zombie monsters have over run the world and humanity is on the brink of extinction.... Stop me if you have heard this one before... no?? Ok I will continue. To survive humanity has started to live in giant forts that are actually large train stations. These stations are spread all over what I assume is the world but itcould very well only be Japan (They show a map of Japan in the intro).  To get from train station to train station humanity has created large trains complete with heavy armor and huge guns. 


The story starts off by introducing your to a young fella by the name of Ikoma. Ikoma is a really smart engineer who is constantly looking for new ways to kill the zombies aka Kabane. Through a series of events he runs into a noble girl named Ayame and her crew as they have to make a speedy exit on a train. He also runs into a young girl named Mumei and the story is off and running. 


The story follows the group as they travel around the world looking for other people and fortresses during their adventures. The big bad is eventually revealed (I am not going to spoil the surprise) and the team must find a way to save the day. 


All in all the story is pretty standard but has just enough flavor to keep you wanting more. The ending is a little funky but it does not hurt the over all story. 


Story Rating: 7 


Art: 


The art in this anime was actually very pleasant! The world they created is both beautiful and terrifying all at once. You see some great shots of the land as the trains speed across the country side.... right before thousands of zombie creatures come running over that country side to eat everyone (yikes)! The series does a great job of blending gory realism with beauty. There are a few scenes later in the series where you can literally feel the sticky goo that is left on the characters after they transform into some gross monster thing. I really have no complaints about the art in this series and feel it was very well done! 


Side Point: I really liked the fighting in this series! The combat is very well done and it is a ton of fun watching Mumei fly around attacking anything that moves! She was a total BA in this series! 


Art Rating: 8 


 Sound: 


There really isn't much to report on the sound from this series. There was nothing really bad to say or positive to say concerning the sound. It was what it needed to be! The intro and credits music was just so so but the in series sound track was pretty decent. I feel like the voice acting was also pretty strong and I really have no major complaints overall. 


Sound Rating: 7 


Characters: 


I have to say one of the strong points in this series for me was the characters. I feel like the show had a lot of characters to work with so they had to do a lot of work to keep you interested in each character. They did a decent job of juggling all the main characters and supporting characters while giving you just enough story to care about each of them. It was nice to see the growth in the main character Ikoma. He started off the series as a pretty strong minded character but you could tell he had some doubt right from the start. By the end of the series he still has his doubts but he makes the choice to stand up for the people he cares about  and he makes a big heroic save when it is needed the most. The other character to watch in this series was Mumei. She actually follows the opposite path of Ikoma in a number of ways as t he series progresses.  I will not spoil any surprises here but know that she is another really fun character to focus on while you watch the show. Look for the little changes in her personality as she moves through the series! I can keep listing off little character moments but I will save you the trouble of reading all that and I will just say every character has an opportunity to grow in this series and that is very neat to see. 


One character complaint I do have is with the big bad. I felt he left a lot to be desired when it was all said and done. He was evil and he was a gigantic butt who effortlessly killed people who followed him, loved him and admired him but that was not enough to save his character in the end. I think when all the smoke cleared he ended up being a bit of a weakling who was to scared to do the one thing that would have made him a real nice villain (no vial for this guy).  His plot to seek revenge was also a little too ordinary for me to really get behind as a true threat. 


Character Rating: 8 


Enjoyment and Overall:


Overall I really enjoyed watching this series and I am excited to see what the movie has in store for us later this year or early next year. I found my self wanting to stay in the world for a little bit longer once the end credits rolled for the last time. The series as a whole has a very normal plot but it is presented well and honestly its pretty enjoyable. I absolutely love the fight scenes in this series, watching Mumei fly around and kick everyone's teeth in was really fun to watch! She was a very fun character and a real highly to the show. I would recommend this to anyone who likes Attack on Titan, berserk, or any other people vs monster anime. It was really a fun series to watch. I would probably watch this one again somewhere down the road! 


Overall Rating: 7 but really more like a 7.5

Okay to start, I want you to know that I just made an account. All for the sole purpose of giving this anime a review. I mean I have felt strongly about shows before but never like this. 
So... THIS SHOW WAS SHIT.
I know everyone compares it to Attack on Titan, which is expected considering its the same studio, director, sound director, composer, etc. It comes with territory. And its premise is very simliar too. I was expecting something amazing, but still different enough. I was sorely disappointed.  
And yes, I will compare it to AoT. It comes with the territory.   
FirstI will start with good stuff. The art and the music. 


ART: Holy shit the art was beautiful. 


This can be seen in scenes with Mumei. Her fight sequences just flowed. You are never prepared for what she will do next. And she has these scenes were she is just lying down but they look so classic. 


And those damn trains. Oh my god they look amazing. There are scenes showing cogs turning and it looks like photos of actual metal cogs. The trains look powerful and like they are a source of pride of both the characters and the artists. 


The kabane look pretty cool too. Yes, they remind me of titans in concept, bit not artistically. The red molten irons veins and the glowing heart in a cage were amazing.  


The whole show has a steampunk look going that I loved. All the outfits and the weapons and the trains looked amazing. That metal look was captured perfectly. 


There are things that look like they are recycled from AoT. Like the walls from AoT appear in kabaneri. And there is a scene where a horde of kabaneri are coming towards the characters and it looks just like one from AoT of titans. It seemed like they were in the same positions and everything. But I can forgive those, considering money issues and it is the same studio. I mean disney has recycled scenes. Its not a major issue for me. It just showed me that I might be too addicted to AoT if I noticed this. At the end it looks nice and that all I cared about.  


My own complain are the shadow black fog thing. That loooked more funny than scary. I mean the animation for the people in the heart looked cool, but from outside, meh. I couldn't take them seriously.. 


MUSIC: And the damn music. It made me feel. It got me pumped when needed and sad when needed. I am considering getting the soundtrack, like how I have for attack on titan and death note. And I hate this show unlike the other two. 


Now onto things that suck. 


PLOT: What the fuck is happening? And I am supposed to care why? 


There were certain things that bugged me. Like the stupid rock. I might have missed it because I would just mentally peace out, but doesn't Ikoma lose the rock at some point. Then It comes back. Then somehow Mumei has it. For a second I thought it would be more than just a rock. They made a huge fucking deal of if artistically. It looked way to pretty to be so useless. 


And they have these super weapon-using kabane. That no one has seen before (I think this was episode 4 or something, in the first half for sure), but they have no impact to the story. For a second I was confused. Did I miss the part, where the characters mention knowing about them? No, this is for sure unique. Mumei has seen them but no one else. Why don't they care about it more. You can't introduce something that is that different from the norm and not have your characters talk about it. 


How people become kabane isn't fleshed out either. So apparently if someone has a bite mark they ar ekilled on the spot to prevent them from becoming kabane. Now if it isn't confirmed where the mark came from, they are isolated for three days. If they don't turn, they are released. One problem, from all the flashbacks, it seemed like turning into kabane takes mere minutes. Where did this this three day thing come from? I will recognize that there was that one pregnant lady who took longer and ended up taking a few hours/days. This does not change the fact that it is still inconsistent. Just give a definite explanation for your world.  


And my biggest pet peeve, Ikoma becoming a kabaneri. The way he does it is really weird. Viruses don't work like this. Okay fine I will work with it. But it would have been nice for the biology to be explained a bit more. Your show has kabaneri in the title. It would be nice to know how they form better. 


But what I don't get is why no one interested in the procedure. It should be revolutionary. It should save lives. This could have been the source of conflict. Higher up people want to use it to save lives, while general public think it better to die. Stuff like that. Instead on one is remotely interested in this. Ikoma saved himself while in agonizing pain (with what appears to be no knowledge of biology). Imagine how people could be saved if this was made a universally accessible. But nope. There are so many scenes where people get bitten, and I am just wondering if they could have been saved by doing the same procedure as the one done on Ikoma. We will never know.


CHARACTER: Right... this was definitely the worst bit. 


Ikoma was actually okay. Not my fave but I didn't hate him. But on the other hand I didn't care about him either. he has the often seen tragic back story. His sister died and Mumei reminds him of her. So he basically gets attached to her. Same old spiel. He is just super cliche.  He was one of the first to be suspicious of the villain, blah blah blah. 


There is this one death at the end, won't mention who, which I think they wanted us to be sad about. I honestly could not care less. This character has been there from the beginning, but they never really fleshed him out. Ikoma cares for him, so I am supposed to? That is not how it works. 


Ayame could have been so much more than she was.  She could have been made into a real leader. yes she has moments where she shines, but they are not as important as they could have been. She also doesn't seem to really grow either. She doesn't seem like a strategist, which a leader should be. You know like Erwin (sorry). You don't really see her make big mistakes. All she does is is just stand around. I kind of wanted more from her. 


Mumei is pretty weird. They tried to write a mentally disturbed character and failed. I don't even know how to put it. She was also overpowered. Her one weakness, where she tends to fall asleep after a huge attack, didn't seem that important except for one mediocre scene that was used to give Ikoma a chance to fight. It like the witers realized that she was overpowered and threw in a last minute solution. She sleeps after an attack!


The worst offender is the villain Biba. What even is he? I don't get his reasons. They never explain it properly. And don't give me the wait for s2 shit. He is dead so I highly doubt that will happen. His reasons never made sense. And his big weapon thing (no spolers) is another technology that isn't explained well. He goes around killing and brainwashing people because reasons. he is also introduced only in the second half. That was a definite weakness. He got too little time. He has all these technologies that need to be explained more. His sidekicks/followers are barely given enough time. do they care for him or not? Apparently some don't because plot reasons. 


And there is this stupid character who has an american accent, I think. I don't get why? Just why? 


OVERALL: So yeah, just don't watch the show. I only did because it has the same director as death not and AoT. I expected better and it didn't deliver. Looked pretty though. But it had no plot. Like porn.

This has mild spoilers!!!:
I really enjoyed the first few episodes and in the end still enjoyed it but i have to say there was a lot of stuff that annoyed me such as a 12 year old girl being op. I thought it was just gonna be humans struggling against kabane but instead at episode 9 stupid pink haired crybaby came in to ruin everything by killing hundreds of innocent people and kabaneri being able to turn into zombies with deadly lazer beams it just really made me struggle to watch the last few episodes. 
Anyway i'm not that good at reviews so that wasa short summary of the stuff in the anime that annoyed me but i don't regret watching it

To be honest this anime was really good. All of the other reviews compare it to Attack on titan.
I can't really compare this anime to attack on titan as I am yet to see it. But from what I saw this anime is done really well.
The story is gripping and keeps me watching. The combat varies which is amazing. There is gun play, dagger play, gun ho rushes and a weird item which the protagonist possess.
Character Development is done quite well in the anime. All characters have a full filling backstory.
But what will draw you to the anime is the action and gore. All episodeshave a great amount of action and gore which will definitely satisfy you

"Attack on titan was THE hit, so let's do another one of that kind" was probably what the creators of this anime thought. It's an original series by the same producers as attack on titan and seraph of the end. Similar characters, setting and storyline make it almost the same in 12 episodes and shorter arcs. But looking deeper into Koutetsujou no Kabaneri itself and all it's details, we get a show that does a pretty good job at what it is supposed to do.
The zombie-like monsters called kabane rule the world in a post apocalyptic world. The hometown of our main character gets attackedand he flees with some other former inhabitants on a giant, iron train. With new developed superpowers and a newly developed weapon, he now tries to fight back against the monsters who took everything from him, even his humanity.

Or to say it in short: "AoT in a zombie world on a train".

Story: 4/10


Animation and Sound fit the tone and atmosphere of the show very well and keep your interest and attention in every scene it shines. Sometimes over the top, it is one of the best things about this anime.

Art & Sound: 8/10


At first the characters in the anime were very well developed and each of them were given equal amount of time to show their own stands in this anime. And after a certain episodes all the characters and their timing were scattered around giving more importance to the surrounding. Pretty basic and nothing new, you still can't hate them and they are often solid.

Charcters: 6/10


Despite the initial expectations on Koutetsujou no Kabaneri and all of the comparisons between this show and Attack on Titan, we think this show proved to be quite decent. Maybe the storyline could have been better, but there is little more we could ask from its characters.

Overall: 7/10

Once upon a time, the producers of Attack on Titan went out for some drinking, during which drinking they began discussing that smashing hit of a series (see what I did there?) and foremost; what they would have changed and made differently. Thus, Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress was born.
That being said, when I finally managed to sit down to watch this series, I pretty much knew what I was up for. A friend of mine had already finished it with much complaint, I had seen a bit about it here and there, though on the whole, I had managed to avoid any spoilers, evenabout the cast and main characters. And on the whole, I must say that I've been left with vaguely pleasant feelings.


Is this better than Attack on Titan, you might ask? Well, no, I'll say. 


The world and premise is a carbon copy of Shingeki no Kyojin, however, the atmosphere and feel is quite different, and in not that bad a way. But where SnK served us a cold dish of realism, Kabaneri tried going for a roast of blazing emotions.


Did it succeed? Well...



The World and Story;;

{a poorly pulled-off Attack on Titan copy}


There has been quite the crop of titan-esque anime/manga this past year- say, like, Owari no Seraphu. And yet in each one of those creations, the inspiration behind the story was far less pathetically, blatantly obvious than in Kabaneri, and nothing can deny that.


Swarms of monsters have made the land uninhabitable? The anime attempts to mangle around with their characteristic traits, but- Check! 

Humans stuck in strongholds? Once again, the nature of these strongholds has been a bit changed up, but still- Check! 

Male lead who will somehow became halfway between monster and human? Check!

Power female sidekick with a tsundere streak? Well, she's petite and childish here, but- Check!

Corrupt officials? Check!

Scout legion equivalent? Check!


The list could go on, but you get the gist of it. And sadly, Kabaneri does a very poor job of being subtle about it or changing up anything about the story's main storyline- male lead by some great coincidence becomes a half-monster (here it's kabane) and obviously is going to have humanity's fate rest on his shoulders.


I just now rather think that I would've preferred Eren's shoulders having the job.


The one big difference is how while in SnK, the general feel of the world was European, in Kabaneri, it's undoubtedly Japanese. Katanas, kimonos and oriental architecture prevail. While AoT has it's vague color scheme of pale blue, sandstone and some grim colors, Kabaneri plunges into the darkness filled with glowing reds and the occasional flash of blue. And looking out at sea of red-eyed kabane- well, shiver me timbers.



Art and Music;;

{pretty blimey good, I would suppose}


What can I say? Looks like they didn't spare money on the animation. With a striking palate of colors that sets the mood well, especially during the battle scenes, as well as uniquely portrayed characters during special moments- most often Mumei- the art was one thing done well.


And as for the sound- well, I'm no good judge of that, but it seemed well done. The opening and ending weren't half-bad, as a whole the voice acting was fine- oh, and yes. The American dude. Damn, I loved the American dude. Felt like home whenever he opened his mouth. Dude saved any moment he appeared in, haha.



Characters;;

{wonderful, as long as you carefully look around the main ones}


This. This was what made the whole of my enjoyment for this anime. 

To my personal tastes, there is nothing as delightful as a well-honed cast of background characters. And in Kabaneri, these side characters and their interactions were exactly that- a delight. 


This was were stereotypes and archetypes were well and artfully used, just as they were well and artfully broken. By giving the background characters a breath of life and personality, but keeping them still as background members of the cast, the show did away with the backdrop of faceless figures and created a believable world around the main heroes in a way they can be proud of.


We have a good dozen faces in our background, half of which do step up to more important roles at times. And I admit to growing to genuinely love these characters we'd see two or three times an episode, sometimes more, sometimes less.


But when it comes to our main cast...


For some reason, it's hard to make good main characters. Probably because they are the ones who most often end up victims of plot convenience and such. But while Mumei and Ikoma could quite comfortably slip into the socks of basic main character stereotypes, they had enough to distinguish them to make both into original characters. Ikoma's never-ceasing grim facing can be a little wearing after a while, though.


Oh, did I forget something? Feels like there's something important I over-looked..?


Ah yes.

Our villain.


Probably the one of the two things that broke this anime for me.

Bascially- no motive. No anything, no sense behind any of those oh so shocking monstrosities. All we know is that suddenly, this guy appears, and since Ikoma immediately dislikes him, he is our bad guy. Why? He seems such a decent fellow! Look, he's fixing that leak! 


Anyway, that was the thing. Usually, we feel something about villains because they have a very well-rooted desire to do something that ultimately crushes the heroes we've grown to care so much about. But with this guy- I'll call him Abba for laughs- we really don't see why he's the bad guy.


Okay, the anime throws him in the next episode doing some horribly unbelievable monstrosities to convince us. But because there is still no conceivable reason for Abba's actions, we just really end up looking at some senseless scenes of brutal violence like, "okay then :\." And the anime goes on to desperately attempt to convince us this guy is pure evil by widening its scale of monstrosities everywhere it can. But the shock value is greatly diminished, seeing as we feel that none of this is really Abba's doing, just what the writers jotted down.


And the complete lack of humanity shown in this guy doesn't help make him evil, just ends up proving that he's a cutout. Which is why the surprise ending in which it seems he gets some small redemption at the very end was actually a pleasant surprise, mainly for the change of pace. Kind of like the persons behind just sighed and sorta gave up, giving us a character slightly more human and less paper cut out.


But once you got over that bit, the character cast actually was very well done, and even on the side of evil as well.


And that American dude. Got to love the American dude.



So, What was the Other Thing that Broke Kabaneri?;;

{let me whisper it- lack of realism. very basic realism. such as cause and effect}


Kabaneri put everything on the card of "determination and emotion" in the way that our main character's ringing battle cry became "we are weak, but we'll still survive!" A fine maxim, if only the anime would finally get on with it and show us how exactly the weak still manage to survive.


The ideological conflict of Kabaneri can be pretty much boiled down to "the strong survive, the weak die" and "f*ck that bullshit, we may be weak, but we still have the right to live, and We Will Live, bogdamnit!" 


Which would culminate in moments when the writers carefully dropped our main pair into more and more impossibly, hopelessly deadly situations, to the point where there was no other imaginable ending but failure and death, and then additionally destroying whatever ashes of belief in miracles existed- to then have Ikoma rile everyone up with a speech about never stopping till they win and survive and ya, ya, we've heard it before, declaring about how they were weak but they would still live.

Okay, sure! I love things like that! 

Only after that great speech, where you'd usually expect to see the character show us what human spirit is, how to get back up and battle the odds, get a new plan or realize something they weren't aware of before that gives them the possibility of victory, you see everything sort of fuzz out a bit and reappear a few minutes later, all nice and cleaned up, because... the plot decided that okay, now they survived? 


In other words, there wasn't even any whipping out of hidden weapons, or turning to faith, or even level-uping to try excusing the fact that now, since that riveting speech has been done with, we can easily stroll out of this impossible situation.  Which weakened this anime immensely. No explanations. No action and reaction.


In other words, if this was Attack on Titan, or Tokyo Ghoul, or any work with as much adherence to realism as Kakumeiki Valvrave, it would have to admit that yeah, those main characters were dead. No getting around it.



Enjoyment;;

{unexpectedly high}


At first, it was on and off. One episode I'd be screaming in wordless rage while ripping my hair out, the next I'd be sitting back like 'you know what, I don't even give a f*ck anymore,' and then I'd suddenly jump up squealing and fist pumping like yeah! 


But the characters and their interactions, the well-fashioned atmosphere, the pleasing art, it all helped swallow down the frankly rage-inducing bits. Plus, the action wasn't half-bad either, and I did grow quite attached to the main group of heroes- the ending left me quite satisfied as well, so that was a plus. 


The biggest surprise for me was the evolution of my feelings towards the 'princess' in this anime. A change from the beginning, where after raging at the screen on put on a sweet smile and decided that if this girl died a slow and painful death, this anime would immediately win itself a high ranking for pure satisfaction, to the ending, where I breathed sighs of relief when she appeared on screen and caught myself wanting to hug her once. 



So, to you, fair reader who desires to give this anime a try, I'll say this- if you're looking for an anime with well-produced fighting scenes and art, that is mostly pleasant to watch, and are aware, that is pretty much a heavily edited Attack on Titan set in a vaguely feudal, steampunk Japan, and are okay with raging at the scene sometimes, I'd say go for it.

Before we begin, let me ask you, the reader, these.
Do you like Resident Evil? Hell yeah you do. Or wait, is that kinda thing not up your alley?
What about things like The Avengers? Pacific Rim? Planet Terror? Hell, Batman v Superman?
Why am I asking these things?
It's because it's important to know one crucial thing about Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress. It is the proverbial Summer Blockbuster deal that we get every now and then stateside. Except this one showed a season earlier than Summer.
But what is it, that people truly enjoy about the things that I mentioned above? The plot? Deep narrative? When you enteredthe theatre, did you honestly think, "Am I ready to experience the depths of the human psyche"? Gods no, I myself knew when I entered the cinema, I wanted to see some damn cool fights and cool robots beating giant monsters.


And for Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress, the show delivers all the stuff you've wanted from a Blockbuster. And it delivers like a train. Ramming through steel barricades. Operated by zombies.


--------Story & Character: 5/10-----------


Probably where it's weakest, is its story. However, even then that's debatable. As someone who's watched so many anime lately that attempts to twist and contort their stories so much, and just absolutely bomb themselves with how unnecessarily complex they are, Kabaneri is a breath of fresh air in that regard. It's narrative and characters are simple to understand, easy to follow. No unexpected left or right turn, or some complicated hoop. It's a simple roller coaster ride.


Is this a bad thing? Absolutely not. Simple is good, eight times out of ten. But this is not to say we could've used stellar writing here - Kabaneri could've done better, especially in its latter half - when zombies stop being a threat on their own, and a human threat is introduced. In most zombie stories though, things will almost ALWAYS draw out to this plot point near the end.


As a tabletop game master who adores running zombie games for his players, as I would say, "When your players kill your best zombie, it's time to send in the corrupt pharma.". Speaking of that; similar to running a tabletop RPG for your friends, the narrative of Kabaneri is made for the maximum entertainment and thrill of its audience. It's a non-stop (ahem) train ride for zombieland, where the most likely thing you're looking forward to next is how much more outrageous the situation can get.


But that's where I find most of the flaws stem from. Had it dedicated itself to becoming maximum B-movie(and it did from the start!), the show wouldn't have wasted so much time meandering around some topics considered "deep" - it could've cut 25% of it, and it would've gone better.


--------Art: 10/10-----------


What can I say? Kabaneri has absolutely GORGEOUS art. Its art is incredibly(and surely intentionally) reminiscent of the highly detailed 80s anime art. Except this time, we have the gift of digital animation and enhancement to make those frames look even more amazing.


If there was any reason to watch this for an anime enthusiast, it would be the art. For the past decade or more, I have not seen an anime THIS pretty and pleasing to look at.


Let's play a little game - when you watch an episode, stop at any point in the show. Any point at all. 8 times out of 10, you will stop at a picture that you could potentially print and post on your wall. You can probably screencap half the show's content, print them them into an artbook, and it would SELL. It is that pretty.


As for the animation quality, it is consistent for most part, characters move smoothly, and cinematography is breathtaking. Again, it's like watching an AAA 80s anime, but better in terms of spectacle. They even have that thing where they show a still picture, and draw speed lines over it and shake the cam to make it look like something's happening. Whoops! Actually, I personally could've done without that.


--------Sound: 10/10-----------


Composer Hiroyuki Sawano is in charge of the soundtrack. This man is known for producing gold out of his hands, and he does not fail to deliver in Kabaneri. His tracks provide excellent mood and atmosphere, and the musical cues and timing of the track is just simply perfect.


Voice acting is good for most part - I especially liked Mumei's and Kurusu's actors.


Opening is a catchy song aptly named "KABANERI OF THE IRON FORTRESS" by EGOIST, and does not hesitate to literally say the show's title as part of the song's lyrics. If the show wasn't 80's enough for you yet, this should solidify that idea already.


The end song, "ninelie" by Aimer is a melancholic and dramatic song that I honestly do not get tired of listening on repeat for an hour, sung in Aimer's signature style.


--------Enjoyment + Overall: 7/10-----------


Did I enjoy the show? Hell yeah I did. Do I think its writing is groundbreaking? Not in the slightest, but I did get thrills over it. I play a lot of horror or shooter games, and while I don't think they're well written, they exist for a reason. 


In the same way, Kabaneri exists as a sort of Blockbuster flick you can watch when you invite your friends over for the night. Will this serve as some historical piece for future anime fans? Actually, perhaps, if only for one reason:


When they look back, and see that only a few studios actually animate their stuff well, they can look at Kabaneri and say, "You mean they made anime look like THAT before? Damn!". I know a few old anime that were not great in story either, but when I look at their art, I think the same thing I mentioned above.


--------Conclusion-----------


So would I recommend this anime to you, reader? If your answer to every question at the first part is "No.", then you may want to turn around and seek another show. If it's a resounding "Yes." to a lot of it, then strap up, grab those snacks, and get ready for one of the prettiest rides you're about to embark - even if the ending isn't as good as you would hope.


Really though, it's when we look for perfection in everything, that we fail to appreciate the smaller things. Kabaneri's existence has a purpose - and that purpose is all that I've said above.

Iron Fortress looked amazing in the PVs, what happened?!
PROS +
                                                             Writing
There are many adrenaline fueled moments that work in the beginning.Music


All the themes helped set the intense mood to everything. This was an anime that cared about the whole package rather than just the story or animation.


                                                       Animation & Art


The character designs by Haruhiko Mikimoto were a mix between modern and retro, nonetheless, they were pretty and cute (the girls, the GIRLS!), of course, the style was great for the whole cast.


For the most part, the action sequences are fluid, bright, beautiful and drawn with care.


CONS - 


                                                            Writing


It`s exhausting to see the cast constantly being thrown in "high intense" situation out of the blue: walking down the street-ZOMBIES!, resting in a village-ZOMBIES!, just talking-ZOMBIES!, haha, of course, I'm exaggerating but still... 


Mumei is a cliche little girl who is capable of such much power. Our lead protagonist is also the chosen one, for the most part, Cold hearted Samurai, etc, etc.


Not much is explained as these 13 episodes of Iron Fortress worked more as an arc to a larger story than a complete project, which I think is a huge problem in anime, they treat a cour as a part to a bigger story rather than making a fulfilling cour regardless if the series will continue or not and instead we feel a little left out. 


                                                              Music


My favorite composer Ryo (Supercell & Egoist) worked on the opening theme with vocalist Chelly, and Sawano composed the ending theme with vocalist Aimer & Chelly. These two songs work exceptionally well in uplifting the feel of the show but do not work in enjoyment because they are way too large and cinematic. I could not enjoy them alone because they are set-pieces to Iron Fortress, which is great conceptually but not great when picked apart. 


A minor con, a random poppy track appears in Mumei`s flashy battle, in the beginning, it was a goofy and threw the atmosphere away. 


                                                           Art


Minor Con: A few times deeper into the cour do we see low-quality illustrations and funny movements, but it`s not much to be bothered with.


----


The effort that went into making Iron Fortress just wasn`t enough but it was beautiful enough to make me not mind viewing another season. 


Essential Watching?: No, it`s not. It`s a beautiful thing to look at and just maybe, you want to see what all the hype was about?

Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress was my 2nd most hyped anime of Spring 2016. Its got a cool setting, its got zombies, and the studio that made Attack on Titan also made this anime. With those reasons, of course this was going to be one of my most hyped anime. Did it live up to the hype though? Ehhh...No. 
[Story]: (4/10)
The show takes place in a steampunk-version Japan set in a middle of the industrial revolution. Monsters called "Kabane" ravages this world and people have built a wall around the city to protect themselves from the undead creatures. One day, a station located in thefar east, has been breach by the Kabanes and the characters must do everything to defend their city and themselves against the Kabane. 


I'm a big fan of the zombie genre. I've been watching zombie movies/TV shows for as long as I can remember. I've seen my fair share of zombie apocalypse stories to know the difference between a half-assed zombie story and a great zombie story. Unfortunately, there's not even a single ounce of anime in this medium that takes place in a zombie apocalypse setting and is even remotely great. High School of the Dead comes to mind but that shit joke of a zombie apocalypse story was infested with fanservice and it made it very hard for me to take that show seriously. There was also School Live but the ending ruined it for me but it was at least better than High School of the Dead. When I first noticed Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress back in March 2016, I was so excited because I told myself that we're finally getting an anime that takes place in a zombie post-apocalyptic world with no big bouncing boobs and a dark atmosphere. 


Since Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress was made by the same studio as Attack on Titan, the similarities between the two shows are plainly obvious. Even the first episode gave me a huge Attack on Titan episode 1 vibe. The story structure is almost the same, the undead creatures here are mysterious and no one knows where they originated from, just like the Titans and the fact that both shows features a walled-in city to protect themselves from the monsters should tell you the similarities between both shows. I think the only difference are the characters. Besides Mumei, which highly resembles Mikasa's fighting technique, the characters are not even comparable to each other. Especially Ikoma. Yea, both Eren and him are the same in terms of both of them having mysterious powers that lets them fight the monsters but their personalities are very different.


Moving on from the comparisons between AoT and Kabaneri, the first 5 episodes of the series was the best episodes the show offered. After that, the show just started to derail itself and eventually suffered a horrible trainwreck at the end but I'll get to that later. For now, I'll only talk about the good parts. The first 5 episodes of the series was pure-adrenaline and exciting zombie action scene that made me want to come back to this show every week. The Kabanes are legit scary and seeing these people trying to survive against the Kabanes was just amazing. Hell, even their paranoia was amazing to watch, albeit at the same time, annoying too. These people literally have no idea what the Kabanes are capable for and that's why I think their paranoia was justified. The fact that these guys are also fighting on a train, which makes you think that they'd be safe there but they're really not, made this series more exciting to watch. Zombies have been done over a million times but fighting zombies while you're on an armored train is something new and fresh for me. 


Behind this exciting zombie action scenes is the unfortunate truth that made Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress a complete mess at the end. By the 6th episode, the plot made it clear to me that it didn't know where it wanted to go. After the exciting 1st arc which was pretty much a set up, the 2nd and final arc was very VERY underwhelming. It felt like they just came up with these arcs because they didn't plan ahead. It felt really meaningless and it had me questioning throughout the 2nd half like "What was their overall goal?". The 3rd arc, which is the final arc in the series, is something you don't want to put yourselves through because of the badly-written annoying-ass villain with a badly-written past. His view on "the weak must die and the strong must live" is just ridiculous and stupid. You might think it's not but just watch the show and you'll see how he stupidly justifies his actions on killing innocent civilians by saying that goddamn quote. 


The inconsistencies and plot holes in Kabaneri is just surreal. Like what's the purpose of doing routine body checks? When these guys are bitten, they eventually turn into a Kabane within a minute or so. They'll know right fucking away if one of the people are bitten by the way they act. What's the point of locking the people you suspect of being a Kabane for 3 days? What the shit?! What is up with Ikoma and Mumei having a special Kabane power-up? Why only them? Why don't the others get a special Kabane power up when they get bitten? Why are the Kabanes so intelligent and how the hell do they form into a giant fucking monster?......And so much more but listing them all here will result in another paragraph or 2 with full of questions. 


To summarize this section of the review, the whole zombie action scenes were nice and the set-up arc was pretty great but the whole show suddenly turned into shit after the Biba (3rd) arc showed up. 

______________________________________________________________

[Art/Animation]: (8/10)

I expect no less from Wit Studio in terms of the visuals because it looks amazing. The character designs looks great and the visuals managed to capture that dark post-apocalyptic world. The animation, on the other hand, was a so-and-so. I mean, it was fun watching the characters running around and shooting zombies up but the animation was mostly inconsistent at the same time. 60% of the time, they'd use those still-images that pretty much ruined half of the zombie action scenes. One of the only scenes where they don't use still-images is when Mumei was jumping around and shooting zombies or when the characters are use their guns (not swords) to shoot and kill zombies. The Kabane's design looks like a generic zombie design but I don't really care about that and those giant CGI Kabane monster design looks horrible. 

______________________________________________________________

[Sound]: (9/10)

I really..really love the show's soundtrack. The OSTs that plays during the action scenes always gives me goosebumps but the insert songs are what's guaranteed to give me an eargasm. It always plays when the characters are about to do something crazy that will lead them to victory and it just fits so perfectly. Now the OP and ED theme song(s)


The OP theme song is "KABANERI OF THE IRON FORTRESS" by EGOIST. Haha, nice song name. Title creativity is overrated anyways. This OP is one of the best OP I've ever heard for this season. It has that scary/apocalyptic tune that fits with the show's atmosphere and I love Egoist. The ED theme song is "ninelie" by Aimer with chelly (EGOIST). Aimer is one of my Top 10 favourite anime singers ever since I heard her OP in UBW. And.....she does it again with her great performance in this ED. 

______________________________________________________________

[Characters]: (5/10)

If you're here for bad-ass female characters accompanied with a bad-ass main heroine who can kick ass and a main protagonist who has a hidden special power like Eren from Attack on Titan then you're in for a treat. If you are, however, looking for character development then you're going to be disappointed as this show is seriously lacking in character depth and character development.  


The main protagonist of the series, Ikoma, is somewhat similar to Eren from Attack on Titan. Both characters have hidden special powers and they both have one goal in mind; Kill the monsters that's ravaging this land. Ikoma's past is really poorly written and it isn't even expanded nor explored, making it very hard for me to sympathize with what he was going through throughout the series. All I know was his family member (was it his sister? I forgot) died because a Kabane bit her and that's it. I don't know anything more about Ikoma's past and I don't even know anything more about Ikoma's sister other than being bitten by a Kabane. I was left wondering why I should care for her. Besides her being part of Ikoma's family, they didn't give me any reason why I should care for her. There's actually another post-apocalyptic series out there called "God Eater" where the protagonist went through the same experience and did a much a better job showing on why we, the audience, should care about the protagonist's dead family member and why he is what he is today. 


I feel like the only character with good writing is Mumei. Unlike the protagonist, she actually has a well-written past and it justifies why she is what she is today. It was even explored and later expanded in the final arc. At the end, it made me somewhat sympathize with whatever she was doing but I wasn't fully sympathizing with her character because the way they resolved her issue was rushed. This show definitely needed more than 12 episodes to flesh out Mumei's character. No, this show needed more than 12 episodes to flesh out ALL of the characters because they are either not developed or under-developed as fuck.


Biba, the main antagonist of the series, is now the most hated villian in the series. People hate him not because he's a villian but because he's a stupid-ass villian with a stupid writing to try and justify that whatever he was doing is completely just. Also, the plot twist about him at the end of the episode is way too abrupt and it really came of out of nowhere. It seemed like an asspull to try and shock the viewers. The introduction of Biba is what ruined the final arc for me. I literally couldn't handle the stupidity of this f*cking character and it made it very hard for me to finish the last 2-3 episodes of the series. 

______________________________________________________________

[Enjoyment]: (7/10)

Believe it or not, I actually enjoyed the series, not because of the story or the characters but because of it's setting and the enjoyable zombie action scene. I am a big fan of the zombie genre after all so seeing the characters fight zombies in an armoured train was very thrilling. Kabaneri is one of those "turn off your brain and you'll enjoy it" type of anime. 

______________________________________________________________

[VERDICT]

"Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress" is now the 2nd anime from Wit Studio that is similar to Attack on Titan (First one being Owari no Seraph). If you're looking for thrilling action scenes or if you're the type of person who likes to watch shows that are set in a post-apocalyptic world then this is the show for you. However, if you're looking for a show with a great story or well-written characters with great character development then this ain't the show for you. If you're one of those people who are desperately waiting for the 2nd Season of Attack on Titan then this show will feel the gap for at least a few months while waiting for the 2nd Season. 


[OVERALL]: (6.5/10)



Pros:

+Dark and Scary Post-Apocalyptic Setting

+Thrilling Zombies Action Scenes

+Nice Visuals

+Epic and Goosebump-Inducing Soundtrack

+Main Heroine of the series is a bad-ass


Cons:

-Weak Plot

-The Show felt like it didn't know where to go after the introductory (1st) arc. 

-Use of Still-Shots in Action Scenes can be off-putting

-Lack of Character Development for most of the characters

-Horrible and Badly-written Antagonist

-Weak and Rushed Ending

-Plot Holes and Plot Inconsistencies

Kabaneri is an anime where collectively as a whole is a below-average show, but when looking at the components that make it what it is, aspects of the show are simply amazing. When Kabaneri came out, immediately it was compared to Wit Studios (the studio that made Kabaneri) hit, Attack on Titan. Do not go into Kabaneri looking for Attack on Titan. In fact, the two shows are nothing alike except for the world structure of humanity hiding behind walls for human-eating beings, in Kabaneri's case, this was zombies. The feel between these two shows are completely different, and each show focuses on one componentof the show more than the other. 


Story: 3


Kabaneri has a weak story. It has a weak plot. This is what turned off many viewers, such as myself. The thing is that from the beginning, it is clear to see that this show wasn't really going to go anywhere with a rich plot and storyline. This show was going to focus on one aspect and one aspect only--action. I like to think of Kabaneri and compare to the American movie, Mad Max (2016), in that both are action heavy with stunning fighting scenes. Don't go into this show looking for plot. This show is a thrill ride that is only going for making the viewers hyped. For someone like me, who definietly values plot more than action, Kabaneri was not exactly my cup of tea and I didn't enjoy it as much. The first half was full of action and thrill, and at that point, I accepted this show as a mindless show that was just there to look pretty and be hype. It wasn't until the second half of the show when a lackluster plot was introduced that I was turned off immediately. It was clear that the only purpose of this plot introduction of the main antagonist, Biba, was to provide a conflict that will in turn give closure to the end of the 12 episode when our protagonist, Ikoma saves the day. This conflict and plot point was so rushed and unbelievable that when the ending came it was so anti-climatic that I checked every two mintues to see how much longer I had to watch this trainwreck. The main problem with Kabaneri from it becoming an enjoyable, mindless show that it's supposed to be, is that it took itself way too seriously than it should have. All the components were there for it to be a great show, even with the terrible plot, if it didn't take itself too seriously than this would've been a show that I would've enjoyed. I watch plenty of anime that have no plot and enjoy them, and that's because the show is what it's supposed to be. In all, the plot was one of the biggest 

downfalls of this show. 


Animation: 9


Now if Kabaneri does one thing amazing, it's its animation. It has this old throwback look that is pleasing to the eye. Everything about the visuals is done right. The animation is simply gorgeous especially during the fighting scenes and the scenes fill with thrill and action. The characters are also gorgeous to look at as well (for the exception of Ikoma's hair, which I absolutely hated until he finally cut it). The eyes were my favorite part to look at during this show because it was just so beautiful to look at. The scenery has great detail and brings the setting to life. The zombies look creepy  and also animated well. The animation of Kabaneri is a huge plus. If you are someone who loves to see the occasional show for the art, scenery and animation such as Rolling Girls (also done by Wit Studios, what a coincedence??) then this is a show that you should watch. This show is gorgeous to look at. 


Sound: 8


The sound is the last redeemable factor of Kabaneri. It is also very nice and all the tracks are used at the right time such as during high action scenes or when there was a slow moment. The opening and ending are great. I'm a big fan of Egoist and Aimer, so that earned extra points for me. The voice actors did a fine job as well. It was personally entertaining to Yuki Kaji play a side character of the show that is influenced by Attack on Titan where he voiced Eren. And of course Mamoru Miyano can do no wrong in my eyes so he was the only thing I actually like about the terrible antagonist, Biba.


Characters: 2


In my opinion, the characters trump the rushed plot in how terrible it was. The characters were bland and stuck to one identifying cliche. I hated Ikoma as a main character (that hair, that hair!!!), I just found him to be boring. Of course, everyone compares him to Eren as a main character continuing the Attack on Titan vs. Kabaneri comparisons. Ikoma is a smart character, but he just seemed to be another cliched protagonist among a cast of bland characters. The only character that I remotely liked had to be Mumei, and even then, her character was pretty boring to me. She was the only character who went through character development, albeit how terrible the development was excuted. Even character deaths weren't impactful to me because I couldn't connect to any of the characters. To me, they were just gorgeous looking dolls with no personality. 


Enjoyment: 1


If someone asked me how much I enjoyed Kabaneri, I would say it was a complete waste of my time and was just garbage in my opinion. Personally, it wasn't my type of show. Or rather, it would be my type of show if excuted well. The execution was so poor that I wanted to gouge my eyes out. Scratch that, if I gouged my eyes out I wouldn't be able to see the fabulous animation. Kabaneri is a perfect example of a show that will fail to test time and will quickly be as forgotten as Wakako-Zake (if you don't get the reference, my point exactly). When reviewing something, I try to look at it objectively and while I'll personally feel a certain way, if a show does something good then I'll admit its merits instead of focusing on what it did wrong. However, when talking about enjoyment, this is where I will be as subjective and biased, because this is all about my own personal enjoyment. 


So in final words, Kabaneri is a gorgeously animated trainwreck that just took itself way too seriously than needed. Along with a terrible plot, anti-climatic ending, and a bland cast, this show just was not up to par with some other shows airing during the Spring 2016 season. Should you watch it? Not really. Unless you like gorgeous animation and mindless action, then you might want to pass on this. 


Overall: 5/10

First things first: Koutetsujou no Kabaneri tried to be Shingeki no Kyojin, with the theme and the emotional appeal, but its construction is light years away from the immersing wolrd Attack on Titan gave to me.
The animation and artwork is quite decent, the atmosfere might get you hyped up in the begging, but the history and character development lacks coherence, and that goes really realy bad for me.
The thing that really made me drop this anime  was the "science". Okay, most mangakas don't do much research, or don't really care, and this is quite a common problem that makes a lot of anime lessenjoyable for me. In most cases, I will ignore the lack of logic for the sake of a cool story, but kabaneri distorts and misuses so many basic concepts in a way that doesn't match at all the tone they're trying to set for the story.\n
The story might have got better from the point I dropped, for sure, but I would never be able to enjoy it.

This anime does not deserve the "hate" it is getting. I would not dare say that it is original, that it is superbly extraordinary, that it is anything new, because we all know that this anime looks like Shingeki no Kyojin and even the Walking Dead and most of everything we can watch these days. The story is already known to us all, and hey, maybe most of us have watched something like this. But you know what? The execution of this anime is still great nonetheless. I would not be judging it based on comparison to other animes, because this one, for me, stilldoes its job and what it's supposed to do. 


The art is not your generic art style--nothing trying to be "moe" or ecchi. Nothing was sexualized, nothing was made to be cuter than reality is supposed to be. And though I am not a fan of these "classic" art style, I still did love it. It was a serious anime, and it is made to be just that (with a little touch of comedy now and then).


The characters had great and reasonable character developments. I loved Ikoma though he gets a lot of hate. Ikoma was not supposed to be strong, but he is trying to be. And I love how they progress his character not quite quickly, but reasonably for someone who is in his position. Same goes for the other characters. They were all not made to be perfect. There would be times that you would hate some of them, but that is the point. That is what your are supposed to feel. That is what the writers want you to feel. Characters aren't meant to cater to your needs, and not all characters are made to be liked or loved. They are meant to be flawed just like humans, and they also want to show us that you learn that way. I will emphasize yet again: THEY ARE MEANT TO BE THEMSELVES. NOT EVERY CHARACTER NEEDS TO CATER TO YOUR NEEDS. (There were animes that characters don't even have characters--the characters are just there to cater to audiences and character fluctuations are all over the place, and for me, that is too shallow--liking characters that are just that. AND PEOPLE ACTUALLY LIKE THAT?) This anime brings you characters that are reasonable no matter how small that reason is. 


I definitely enjoyed this anime. The action is there and it is amazing. And as I've mentioned earlier, though it is not original or anything new, it is not bad. It is still enjoyable, with all the adventure they faced and the trials they had along the way. 


Overall, try to enjoy the anime instead of complaining here and there. The problem with people nowadays is that they shit on everything and fail to see the good in every anime. Animes are meant to be enjoyed! And for me who is a fanatic of adventures and intense action, this one does it.

I made this review out of disappointment and mostly - to warn potential viewers.
One of the most hyped animes this season. Does it live up to expectations? tl;dr NO.
Thanks to your overly-generous budget - you seem to have please the eyes and ears of the viewer (myself at least).
EGOIST and Aimer are great - considering the setting and theme of the anime - their OP and ED sets a good scene, and lends supposed credibility that this will be an epic. The BGM throughout is generally on point and really bring the scenes to life.
The MC's Voice Actor really bring the character to life -in fact at times it made the animation and idealized character feel inconsistent to the voice. Also, what's the point of Suzuki (?) a gaijin-ed speaker. Was it to mock ? Or comedic relief? It felt unnecessary. However, the rest of the characters were also so-so at best, with linear personalities - and really missed opportunities to utilize the good visuals. \n\n
The story - started good. Ended like shit. Actually it ended like bad rice. It had good pacing initially - but it soon 'derailed'.\n\n
Ah right, <SPOILER> the Rice. It's the fucking center of another MC. Jeez, are you kidding me? Is this Sasha the Potato Lover from AoT? Gosh, give me a break - you spent more than half the anime trying to set up a sad and pitiable character then you tell me it's for rice. <SPOILER END>\n\n
Concluding my rant, this anime seems to be a well-started, badly completed attempt at contending the Attack on Titan fame. I'm sorely disappointed. You can watch it for yourself and find small bits to save this. I'll give you that hope.

I dont usually do reviews (i do plan to start and i chose this anime to be the first)
Although some people compare this to Attack on the Titan, they are both wrong and correct, there is many similarities between to, for example, in both animes enemy of mankind shows one day and start attacking humans, in one it eat humans in second biting and turning them into enemy, there was no much explanation how they came to existance and where they attack first (ok there was some explanations for titans), 
in both, people live in walled cities (stations), in both, there is group of survivors- solders fighting the enemy, in both there is those that are neither human or the enemy(titans or kabane),


in both there is serum that can turn humans into titans (kabaneri), 


so there is lots of things that make Attack of the Titan and Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress similar to each others,  both of them have good storys, although i like KnK(Koutetsuju no Kabaneri), Art is similar to AoT(attack of titans), sound is far better, Characters, could be better but they are okay, overal i like both, but i will say that KnK is better to me, although not good enough to deserve score 10, 


i really hope there will be the second season, this anime deserve it,

Zombies, Steampunk and Trainwrecks...literal trainwrecks.
Probably one of the most hypest anime LA had for Spring 2016 and for the first 8 episodes it was great!, yet come episode 9, BOOM~!!! it just pardon the pun went off the rails and crashed and burned. So what went wrong???..well let's see what went right before seeing what went wrong.
Well for one, the majority of the premise to the characters and of course the threat to humanity were all great. Character wise, Ikoma the "main protagonist" voiced by Tasuku Hatanaka is actually a unique character although he's something of a supporting character to his own anime, as eventhough he has this "smart, yet want to protect everyone mantra on him", LA's favourite character actually goes to Mumei voiced by Sayaka Senbongi the extremely capable Kabaneri fighter. The rets of the train cast consists of the Ayame Yomogawa voiced by Maaya Uchida, the daughter and heir to her family who governs the Koutestujou, Takumi voiced by Yuki Kaji, Ikoma's best friend and Kurusu voiced by Toshiki Masuda, Ayame's bodyguard.


The battles in this anime is exceptional and even more props to the animation studio Wit in making zombie killing through steampunk badassery all the more awesome with the animation styling that's reminiscent of early 90's anime but in a more crisper style to add in how badass some of the battles against the zombies can be.


Finally, LA would like to point out that LA earlier said that Ikoma felt like a supporting character to his own anime and LA says this as it feels more like that Mumei is the central character with all the character development towards her, from her duties to her being a Kabaneri and just knowing more about the world than Ikoma does, now this isn't the horrible thing but it's just something LA would like to point out.


So what's wrong with this anime come episode 9?...well


*****SPOILERS AHEAD (If your still interested in watching this anime, WATCH the anime first all the way then come back and continue reading) ****** 


What's wrong with this anime come episode 9 that made this anime into an utter trainwreck comes in two points, one is another character that appears to be Mumei's "older brother" Biba Amatori voiced by Mamoru Miyano, as not only is his motivations of "being the evil dude" utterly stupid but his "means don't outweigh the actions he did". Biba utterly ruins both the tension of zombies but his motivations in making him the "human villain" is utterly pathetic in comparison to...ohh LA doesn't know "wanting to keep humanity save in order to kill them"...yes you read that right, Biba is just that stupid. the other point?...concerns LA's favourite character, Mumei, sure her character development before Biba's appearance was getting somewhere but come Biba, she too becomes stupid and blind to what she is doing. LA utterly hated episode 9 because of this and systematically ruined the concept of zombies killing humans AND ruining LA's faovurite character all in one fell swoop. Way to go Koutetsujou no Kabaneri.


But that was only episode 9, it could redeem itself right???...well for the final episode yes it oddly did (for LA anyways), they still kinda rushed it for the build up of this ending with some deus ex machina's that goes unexplained as such it's writing for the characters, especially with Ikoma though his powerup and "we can save Mumei cure" was a rushed deus ex machina, it got kinda worse when Mumei was turned into a damsel in distress, however the finale still gave an awesome finale to the point LA could "forgive" some of the stupid writing that lead up to this awesome ending.

This is my first review, so i'll make it short.

WTB a good steampunk anime :(

What should I say? It's happening again. Packing a really good potential into short rushing 12 episodes and they have done that really... really... bad. So many things left unanswered, messy character building, and a very good story wasted just like that. I don't say that Koutetsujou no Kabaneri is bad but I would say this anime is not that very good either.
They started this anime with a good (and I think) perfect flow, an outstanding animation and music (thumbs up for Sawano Hiroyuki, EGOIST, and Aimer), and last, interesting characters. They got Ikoma, a Kabaneri nerd who creates a piercing gun that could pierceKabane's heart but has some sister complex issue, then they got a perfectly characterized Mumei, a super OP badass Kabaneri who has a fear of being weak. It was all perfect until they threw a huge bomb into Biba's character and made Biba's character messy as hell. Yup, I said it.


The biggest problem in this anime problably in Biba's character development. I think if they give more information about Biba's background and not throwing Biba into some quick bizzare yet very evil scheme that destroys his character completely (and problably the rest of the series). Biba needs some time to be shympatized by the audience and made into a good character. Then again I want to blame that Koutetsujou no Kabaneri was too short and learning from past animes, a huge universe like this anime should have more episodes than 12 to explain whatever happened to the universe, character developments, and resolving whatever the problem is.


Overall, this anime isn't bad but it's not that very good because of the story that felt rushed and a character (Biba) being undeveloped even he is the main antagonist. But still, I would recommend this series for you who loves a mindblowing animation or eargasming music and soundtrack. The animation is so great yet the music is really... really... great. Lastly, it would be great that if this series has a sequel to resolve whatever they have done to this great potential.
