I am not going to describe every single detail about everything (because others are already doing a better job with it) but after seeing a lot of poor ratings, I have decided to write a review because...
YOU SHOULD NOT LET THESE REVIEWS STOP YOU FROM WATCHING IT. 
Just try the first 2 episodes. 
This anime is worth a watch. Of course, it depends on your preference but if the story is great. Sure there are some similarities with Attack on Titan but come on, I'm pretty sure Attack on Titan has its reference from the old animes as well. 
It just ticks me off ashow some people keeps comparing it to the other anime. If you focus on the story and the development of the characters, you'll enjoy watching more.\n\n
The illustration is splendid. One of the best, if not the best, artwork I've ever seen in anime.

To sum up the anime: 6 episodes of Attack on Titan + 6 episodes of Guilty Crown. 
The beginning was great, setting is near identical to AoT except with zombies and trains. Art is no less than that of AoT either. The studio did a fabulous job setting the tone for the anime that you can actually feel the fear and despair. Characters are rather bland but the plot alone is enough to keep your attention. 
Then it turned into Guilty Crown (which I really disliked). While the characters remain undeveloped, the plot starts to fall apart. The story becomes harder to follow by theepisode, and nearly no exposition was given. The MC's plot armor becomes so thick he can overcome any threats no matter how ridiculous it seems.\n\n
So take the average of your score for AoT and GC, and that is what you should expect going into it.

Koutetsujou no Kabaneri was a very good idea and the first couple of episodes were very good! The art was good but not life changing and I cannot complain about the sound quality or the unforgettable opening song. The part it is most lacking in is character development, sure the main characters got developed a tiny bit but the supporting characters did not get developed at all (I was really hoping there would be some romance). Since it was made by the same people who created Shingeki No Kyoujin it bears a lot of similarities in story and art style but the story is alsoa lot more rushed than AOT.

What is with the negative reviews!? 
I think the reason why everyone is so disappointed is because it wasn't like Attack on Titan. However, everyone fails to realize that it's NOT Attack on Titan. It is true that is gets its inspiration from the show, but it is completely different. 
Honestly, I think it's MUCH BETTER than Attack on Titan, especially for the characters.  
Ikoma is smarter and more tactical (more than Eren ever was). All the characters have their reasons for what they do and what motivates them. One thing I particularly enjoyed was the character development. AND YES THERE WAS MORE DEVELOPMENTIN 12 EPISODES THAN THERE EVER WAS IN 25 OF ATTACK ON TITAN. The side characters learned from their own mistakes and became better, not just the main ones. Ayame became a better leader. Mumei realized what she was doing and began to trust the right people. All the people on the train started to realize that Kabaneri were nothing to fear. Even Takumi grew some balls and saved his friend. 


The art style was amazing as expected from the same team. 


The music was brilliant because of Sawano Hiroyuki. I'm already a fan of his music. He's amazing at what he does.


The storyline was great. I don't think it was generic at all. You guys want to talk generic shounen? Look at Fairy Tale and Bleach? Oh yes I did go there. 


Honestly, I think it was one of the better shows from the spring season this year. You should give this anime a chance. It was one hell of ride. XD


~~SPOILER WARNING~~


Side Note: Everyone seems to hate Mumei. Mumei was not a bad character and nor was she annoying. I'd like to think she was brainwashed from her "brother." However, she DID redeem herself in the last 2 episodes when she finally realized what she had done. She tried to stop her brother, but before she could, she was already forced into submission. She developed as well as a character. People hate her for her mistakes and faults, but I think that's what makes her truly a good character. The fact that she has faults, but tries to fix herself. That's what makes her human.

Meh. It was great until it turned into a human v human thing with the zombies just being a background. They should have focused more on human v zombie survival and less on the other boring guy wants to do a political power grab and look at all this drama surrounding it. 
Also apparently the review has to be longer so I dont really know what else to say other than you should watch it if you have nothing better to do and have an itch for Attack on Titian. 
Overall it gets a meh/10. Seriously, its just an ok show that wont have youfeeling anything when you finish watching. Its just there.

People: Are you Human or Kabane?
Me: NEITHER!
People: !!!
Me: I AM A REVIEWER!!!
People: Get out of here you weeb
Me: WAIT!
Me: Oh well
Anyway, aside from that, this is my review of Koutetsujou no Kabaneri.
Many people say it's a ripoff of Attack on Titan and yes, the similarities are undeniable.
But hey when you think of it, yeah all these survival anime need the cliche's to make sense, or be interesting. I know, we're all sick of the cliche's like:
They all live in a protected area that the monster supposedly can't enter.
One of the main characters is half, part, or has powers of the monsters they are fighting.
MC lookslike he will die, DOESN'T <-But hey that's like a lot of anime.\n\n
But anyway, if we didn't have those cliche's it would just be a boring bloodbath.\n\n
But Kabaneri....how do I say it? It had potential, but with only 12 episodes, of course it was rushed.\n
So first of all, I want to talk about the characters. The MC, Ikoma, seems interesting, but then he really doesn't get much development, pretty much all the characters get of their backstories, is of their families or people important to them getting killed by Kabane.\n\n
The other character is Mumei, dear god she is annoying. She comes off as this badass chick that has no fear or something..but.\n
One moment, she's protecting people and playing with children, the next minute she's freakin sassin off to to Ikoma for no reason and just being a retard. She makes no sense and I really didn't care for her.\n\n
Second thing I need to rant on is the antagonist, sure he might have a grudge on his dad, but that doesn't give him a reason to KILL EVERYONE. I mean seriously!?\n\n
But anyway, enough of the ranting, let me talk about Kabaneri's good points.\n
First off, animation and sound, both really good, especially the OSTs, which is no surprise since they were composed by Sawano Hiroyuki. Animation, I liked it. It's sort of old, but new, it's hard to explain it, but if you look at their eyes (Especially the girls) it has a old style, but it's new? But yeah anyway. \n\n
The anime does keep me interested, and was more gory than I thought. Before I watched the anime, one of my MAL friends Avalnych, he gave me a heads up saying \n
"That anime needed more episodes"\n\n
And yes, he was right, if this anime had had 24 eps, and good development, I probably would've given it an 8, but unfortunately with it not fulfilling it's potential, it gets a 6. But don't skip this anime just because people say it's a ripoff of all those other post-apocalyptic anime, it really depends on the person and what you've seen. If you've seen Attack on Titan, Black Bullet, God Eater, Sidonia no Kishi and all those other anime, you'll probably just hate on it and say it's a ripoff.\n\n
However if you have not watched those anime, this one isn't a particularly bad one to start with.\n\n\n
Thank you for reading my review.

This is my first review so bear with me. After reading many criticisms about Kabaneri, I felt I should defend it with some of my opinions on the show. I will avoid spoilers as much as possible, but some may slip out to exemplify a strength or weakness; you've been warned. 
1. Story (5-Mediocre)
Obviously, the story is where many people begin the bashing. It is Attack on Titan: Zombie Edition for most people watching, and I can see it as well. Despite this fact, we have to look at the person who directed the show: Tetsurou Araki. Araki has directed another show, would you liketo guess what it is? He directed Attack on Titan as well, so obviously some of his story elements might have carried over from his other work. I've also seen comparisons to Wit Studio's other work Owari no Seraph which is, like Kabaneri, Attack on Titan: Vampire Edition. I'm not trying to label this as an Attack on Titan knock off, but it is so hard to avoid the comparison. I can rationalize it with the director and studio both working with similar content, but the story is most certainly not original. This applies to the manga as well, coming out after Owari no Seraph and Attack on Titan. 


2. Art (8-very good)

If this show was entirely hand-drawn, this could've been a 9 or 10 easy. The show's strengths are most certainly in the animation and sound and at times I was distracted by these over the shoddy writing making the show enjoyable. The animation definitely emphasizes the hard work of Kabaneri's animators and the quality should not go overlooked. My favorite scene, which exemplifies Kabaneri's strengths in animation and sound, is probably the transformation of Ikoma which has Aimer played over the sequence making it more emotional and dramatic. The combination of the music and art is what really carries the weight of the show. 


3. Sound (9-great)

I covered this in art since the art looks nice and there isn't much else to say about it. The sound's combination with the art is what balances the great qualities of the show. With Masafumi Mima (Attack on Titan, Fullmetal Alchemist) in the sound direction position, the show would, no doubt, have great sound and music. The opening and ending tracks are handled by EGOIST and Aimer, two of my favorite Japanese singers who work on anime. Many people say ufotable's Fate Stay/Night had the best opening ever because of the beautiful track by Aimer "Brave Shine". Aimer once again does great work with the ending track and the song that plays at the end of episode 11 and the Kabaneri theme by EGOIST is also outstanding. The suspenseful background music is implemented effectively and helps raise the emotions of the show. 


4. Character (4-decent)

If you've read my bio, you know anything under a 7 is not a good thing. I'm saying this because "decent" is probably still too generous of a word. It's funny since I gave story a 5 and the word for that rating sounds worse: mediocre. All the characters are stock (stereotypical, for those who don't know) and carry tropes seen many times before. The development of characters is also non-existent or foreseeable if a change is necessary to drive the plot. Many of the characters also don't seem to be very intelligent in assessing situations and it normally turns bad because of this poor decision making. Biba, the antagonist, is also bland and poorly developed; seeking revenge on his father while sacrificing most of the remaining Japanese population - what a great plan. 


5. Enjoyment (7-good)

Despite the story and character being another rendition of generic storytelling, the way it is animated and orchestrated overpowers its weaknesses. Sure, if you  want to be critical of the work, it is not something noteworthy but if you want to watch beautiful animation with great action sequences backed by a great score, this show will most certainly be enjoyable despite the writing.


6. Overall (7-good)

Maybe this is being too generous since when you average all of these you get a 6.6, but I'm still not convinced that this show is garbage due to its story and characters. If we criticized shows for being mundane in storytelling, every show would be rated horribly outside of maybe 1 each season. Now, my grading scale does not excuse 7's or lower since a 7 is meant, in my opinion, to express a show with quality in some areas and flaws in others. Kabaneri is most certainly a flawed show in more ways than one, but if we ignore the hard work of the animators and sound director we would be shaming not only this show but other shows that are fun to watch. I'm normally very critical of shows with bad writing but I've become more docile in grading since some people watch shows to see action and adventure - something Kabaneri does effectively - and many good shows could be arguably the same monster of strengths and flaws (I'm looking at you Attack on Titan; yes, I grade Attack on Titan the same as this since I don't believe that shows was written well but the animation and sound carried most of the burden). So saying the show is good seems adequate, especially since it is too similar to Attack on Titan with almost the same people working on Kabaneri. I see people's criticisms and I agree, don't get me wrong, but the show isn't horrible. I want to continue, but it is repetitive to continue saying what is good and what is bad in relation to other reviews (which the guidelines say NOT to do).


Would I recommend this show? For someone who wants a gritty action, steampunk-fueled, adventure, most certainly!

Frankly, I think people mistaken the flashy animation for potential because it never had much even once the premise was set.
Essentially, these monsters that isolated mankind were Zombies with gold hearts. Such an enemy for me is too one dimensional but I was hoping for a narrative that would add a new layer to this. Unfortunately, this one didn't. There was no hint at how these came to be and their killing technique failed instill any fear in the audience unless a victim screamed loud enough. Yes, over dramatic.
The protagonist was the typical mouthy, ambitious shounen protagonist who wanted to prove a point. I'm ratherused to this common troupe, and was ready to put up with this having realised that he was quite intelligent. For example, he made a very cool gun that killed Kabane more easily proving his  expertise as an engineer. Unfortunately this is as far as his intellect goes.


There was definitely a political undertone to this that developed as the story went on. At first, it seemed too cryptic for the sake of mystery but once it came to light, it still didn't make sense or hint to something groundbreaking. This brings me to my next point. The motivation of the villain. I didn't understand the liberation he was referring to on episode 9 for example. His reasoning didn't make an ounce of sense nor did Ikoma's reason for being suspicious of him. Regardless of whether he was right, how he came to it didn't make sense.


This is a short anime series, so I didn't expect in an in-depth story. But there's rushing and skipping story elements and then, there's leaving huge plot holes. These plot holes couldn't be ignored, sorry. But okay, the story could have been marginally poor but forgiven if the anime possessed good amount of "epicness". Annndddd it failed at this too.


The fight scenes was basic. You had steampunk guns, half zombies, samurais and the fight scenes were so mediocre. Overall, things were more bright than visually satisfying. Please do not let the unnecessary lights fool you, there was little substance in any of the action. The soundtrack which may have been overlooked by others didn't fool me either. It was the biggest give away that this was put together in a formulaic way to mirror AoT's success. The music fitted the tone rather than the show itself. I personally felt it was very unauthentic. 


Frankly I could literally smell the lack of soul in this anime.

Having watched a short show like Dimension W that showed how to cut huge chunks of plot satisfactorily, this was inexcusable. And having watched another AoT "wannabe" in the form of Black Bullet, that actually provided a story that's unique enough to stand on its own. This was a shameless copycat. I have come to realise this didn't do much of anything well. I feel duped by how it was positioned because it never found its own identity but tried to extract different elements to form a winning formula that still produced a poor result.


In summary:

Story 3/10 - It didn't make sense nor did the character's motivations.

Soundtrack 3/10 - Felt forced and overkill.

Art - 6/10 It was ok.

Character - 4/10 - Squandered potential.

Enjoyment - 4/10 -When I realised this was going nowhere, I just wanted to be done with it.

It is of no wonder that people often compare Koutetsujou no Kabaneri (Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress) and Shingeki no Kyojin (Attack on Titan) - produced by the same studio, WIT studio, and having a similar plot line. But I am here to write a review of Koutetsujou, and not writing a comparison essay.
Kotetsujou is interesting to a degree, but its charming points have been used in other anime (aka SnK/AoT) that it was somewhat compared to. In a steampunk-old Japan setting, the story revolves around MC Ikoma who is a steam smith as he fight against the zombies, whose heart was almost impossible topenetrate due to some sort of iron cage. You have an iron train and hordes of zombies as you follow him and the other minor characters into a journey! The plot isn't quite there, sadly. It was lost a few episodes in. It has an interesting start, then it touched upon the ugliness of human's soul, and a deus ex machina good ending - as far as the anime ends. I've only seen three plot holes so far, which happens towards the end, and how it happens is by God's commands. There may be more but I have failed to see it, or have been forgotten through the weeks.


The characters of Kotetsujou aren't too bad, but they lack of fleshing out the characters. There are only three characters in the whole series is given the opportunity to show their pasts through flashbacks. Their characters remain the same from start to finish, though second MC Mumei have slightly grown in terms of thoughts. Apart of the two MC (Ikoma and Mumei), the others are just there to foil a little of the MC's behaviors. The antagonist have a rather silly motivation, though I could see his point, but his actions was somewhat retarded. "Human population is declining, but I must take revenge and so they need to die." I have failed to understand this logic. Sometimes, the normal humans would achieve bad ass moments, and those are the only times I would remember them. Unfortunately.


Kotetsujou's saving point is its art. It uses dark colors to enhance its normal, grim setting and I could remember a scene full of light to portray the mood - it was excellent. There is a contrast of appearance between royalty and peasants that I really like. It's action scenes merged with 3D animation is eye candy. I am a sucker for good art, and this is one of them. The character designs are not bad - you could easily spot the main characters and the "main" characters. What I didn't quite like is Ikoma's character design. His hair after Episode 1 is weird.


The sounds are not bad. The OP and ED does portray the mood they want to show in the anime. I don't have much to say about this as I don't quite notice or have anything to pinpoint about.


For enjoyment it was alright. Sure, the plot may have been used before in other big works, but I'd say that it's worth to check it out. Kotetsujou will be in my list of great art, but all other parts are moderate at best. Perhaps it has too many characters and too many things to explore that they didn't quite tap into its potential that led it derail from its original motive. Rewatching wouldn't be necessary, for there was nothing left to explore when they have given you almost everything you need to know apart of the plot holes.


Overall it's a little above average because I like the art and fluid animation, and it has, at the very least, an antagonist with motivation that you can hate and portrays the humans being extremely easy to brain wash (which is true if you have the correct ingredients to do so). Many people were disappointed from its hype, but I didn't join the hype train beforehand and have successfully avoided the disappointment wreck. It is worth checking out, even if it was just for the art.

(These are purely my opinions, i understand if you don't agree with them)
I would almost recommend not watching past the first episode since it was done so well, everything was hitting a 7/10 for me in the first episode, I was SO hyped.
The show unfortunately never evolved past the first episode, in fact it devolves since the main character loses sight of his main goal of wanting to exterminate every last...uh, all the undead. I wasn't inspired or captured by any of the characters, they felt like hollow shells that could have been so much more.
The art was really nice, a bit inconsistent and losesa LOT of points for the art of the main character (dat hair and skin colour). \n\n
TLDR: could have been a really good anime. 5/10

"♪Everybody's doing a brand new dance now, come on baby do the locomotion ♫"
They say a good encounter consists of a phenomenal first impression. And that was exactly what this anime accomplished when we snuck in to peek at the mind blowing heat steaming trailer. The first few episodes were a breath of fresh air. Super action packed scenes that were constantly visually stimulating. You were literally on the edge of your seat, as the epitome of coolness exploded right at your face. What a train ride this show turned out to be. If you are all about STEAMPUNK, IRON FORTRESSES, STEEL STRUCTURE, EXPLOSIONS, USIANBOLT ZOMBIES! then buckle up before your steam engine burns out. 


Now unfortunately first impressions can always be overridden if the substance of an idea cannot sustain itself. And subjectively being someone more interested in a "good story" that was when the asmtha kicked in. The smoke of polluted air drained the life out of me. There was too many missed opportunities, rushed moments and I strangely expected more..... But you have to give credit where credit is due. The intentions were very clear. This was nothing but a sit back and enjoy the ride kinda flick. Now that the show is over at least you get to watch it in one go. Waiting every week really did kill the engine.


p.s ( post scriptum ) 

this was a very light review......

♪ these zombies don’t eat braaains,
but they’re still gonna kill us all, 
so all board the steam traaain ♬
choo-choo
That’s the general summary for kabaneri or as it was known before release: "attack on titan: trains edition" or as it’s known after release: "Shit: standard edition".
for those of you who followed along with the show on mal throughout its run you may have noticed the steep decline in score after the final episode, though you shouldn’t really be surprised cause it was declining consistently since like episode 3-4 it was just more of a slow decline, if the public opinion on this show was given physicalform it'd be that of a half built water slide, some twists and curves but eventually going down and just when the pool is in sight the rest of the slide is a straight vertical dive so sudden you smash your whole body in the water and lose consciousness... tortured metaphors aside I think part of the spite people have for this show derives from just how high their hopes were for it at the beginning, the optimistic suckers.


rather than going aspect by aspect let’s just split this review into the Good and the Bad shall we?


the good:

-the animation was pretty good all throughout

-music


that’s about it, and even the animation has to come with an asterisk due to the occasional use of dodgy cg. And of course the music was gonna be good, they had fucking Hiroyuki Sawano AND Aimer, that’s like getting the musical equivalent of a second Christmas with dragons.

if you’re wondering why I didn’t include Egoist above it’s probably because I didn’t really like the OP much, and before you say I’m just some weeby elitist douche with no taste in music I’m only half of that, and I actually really like Egoist, which is why this opening felt so disappointing, I know she can do way better, at least two of the three theme songs for the project Itoh movies are in my phone worn out from replaying them so often. But I guess this is just the best you can get when you force her to work with such lousy material.

Remember how I said this was supposed to be the good section, HA, neither do I.


the bad:

if this series was an adaption everything wrong with it could basically be blamed on the source material. 

SO in no particular order here are the issues I had:

-Bad Characterization: the characters are just so...average at best, in episode 2 or 3 glasses-so-i-look- smart, i.e. ikoma tells his "tragic backstory" ignoring the fact that the question he was asked didn’t justify dumping his entire life story out of nowhere his story is generic, cliché and can be told basically through a 3 second animation of his sister getting bitten and him turning around dramatically, And you know what I find most obnoxious about it? the fact that the characters and indeed the writers seem aware of just how cliché it is since the character he talks to predicts this and flat out CALLS it cliché, and yet still are we meant to care?

another bad aspect of the characters is that everyone besides the main cast seem to have about 3 brain cells between them, they yell, make wild accusations and just generally behave like dipshits, its actually funny how they constantly dis and distrust ikoma and mumei and call them kabane when I’d say the kabane are smarter than they are, please explain to me how these supposedly trained soldiers who've lived their entire lives around kabane can’t seem to tell the difference between a gray malformed lumbering creature incapable of dialogue and a regular dude screaming “DONT KILL ME”. at times they even say shit like: "that’s what a kabane would do" or "in the end, she’s just a kabane"


:|


are you for real you bunch morons?! a kabane is, once again, very clearly visually distinguishable and D-O-E-S-N-T SPEEEEAK, shouldn’t just the fact that they’re telling you to fuck off show that their NOT kabane? I purposefully avoided saying “can't think” because that'd describe 80% of the people in this show pretty well, and at least the kabane can learn sword fighting and boxing, bizarrely.

Let's harp on the characters some more I quite enjoy it, the sheer level of idiocy on display here sometimes borders on self-extinction, honestly these people don’t need the kabane to get wiped out, seems like just five minutes with a sharp object will suffice and I’m not even exaggerating, in one episode one of moss-head's friends pisses of a soldier, and what does that soldier do? he doesn’t let him off with a warning or just arrest him, ya know cause he’s supposed to be an adult and disciplined soldier, no, he literally pulls out his sword and plans to KILL him, and he would’ve done it too if protag didn’t step in, I don’t know who’s dumber, the soldier or the kid who pissed him off cause apparently his plan was to guard against his sword with his bare hands! What’d you think was gonna happen mate? He’d just cut through the fat and get stuck? then you’d have him right where you want him? Mind you this still doesn’t seem as bizarre to me as the fact that he can even be fat when all throughout the show a point is made that food is pretty scarce and you have to ration it.

oh boy I’ve been wailing on the characters for quite a while, and I’m not even DONE. but since I’ve dragged this out long enough I’ll try to summarize the main antagonist as quickly as I can - a huge twat. that should do but if you want a more in-depth description of the scale of his twatiness he’s just so comically evil its obnoxious, if this guy were a video game villain he'd be one of the billionaire morons from the resident evil series who keep investing in zombies and monsters as a brilliant way to take over the world.


-dialogue: mediocre at best, so much so i don’t feel like there’s much to add here really, if that whole "fill belly with rice" line didn’t make your body do a little involuntary “blegh” sound you may want to see your doctor cause apparently your gag reflex stopped working. all its attempts at character's ideologies and philosophies just comes across as generic at best, and just plain bullshit at worst usually whenever stupidly villainous villain guy attempts to justify setting babies on fire and feeding them to their dog, and then him eating that dog.


-kabane: and finally perhaps the most important aspect the show failed at (depending on who you ask) as you may have gathered from the beginning of this review, initially at least, there was quite a comparison drawn between attack on titan and this show, and while many things helped erase that discussion(mostly things like attack on titan not being total shit) the one difference most important between the two is that the titans, while not always, at least at times came across as these truly unnerving, scary fucked up creatures that really helped give a sense of urgency to the show, the kabane on the other hand are basically faster, shoot-in-the-heart-not-the-brain zombies except they’re not even that! cause several times just lobbing their heads off seems to do the trick quite well.


So let’s summarize, at the beginning of this review I said that before its release kabaneri seemed like: "attack on titan: trains edition" but now it can be seen for what it was meant to be and what it ended up being, it was meant to be "Attack on titan-ish: hope you didn’t forget attack on titan exists, here’s something to hold you over till then" and what it ended up being is "Not even really attack on titan-ish: we probably should have just taken the time and effort put into this and released attack on titan sooner huh..." and now that I ranted all over you(and even if you didn’t agree thanks for reading this) i guess I’ll just make like kabaneri and have a shit conclusion, bye.

I myself rated this anime a 6/10 but doing the calculation overall it was a 7. The story reminded me of attack on titan with monster trying to kill people with a main character who wanted to kill all of these said monsters. I like the whole idea of people coming together to fight a common enemy, but the story kinda lacked what i was hoping for in the story. I will come back to why I didn't like the story and where it went later on. The Art of the anime was really go especially in close up shots of character where it hada paint like look to the characters. Some of the animation wasn't great or they looked like they cut corner with close up so they didn't have to animate certain parts but it was ok overall other than those parts. The sound track I cannot say much about but it was the made by same composer of attack on titan's sound track Hiroyuki Sawano. I liked the soundtrack for this anime but I will have to listen to it by itself to say how much I truly enjoyed it. The characters of this anime were not really all fleshed out and their back story's were rather lack luster. I did not really care for many of the characters. The only one I liked were those that looked cool and not many really did. But than again what can you do for character development in a 12 episode anime. The only characters that were developed were the main characters Ikomu and Mumei. Everyone else was just kind of there just to be there. Ikomu was really just very linear and had little change to his character and Mumei was an annoying cocky brat for the most part but than again she was only 12 so ir is within reason. Back to the story... Without spoiling anything the story could have had more potential. They could have tried to figure out the origin of the monsters, find a cure, explore without the use of the trains, maybe even had a war between opposing factions or cities ( rather then the short one they kinda had), and many more. The story deiced to go along a rather boring plot and the "superpowers" the characters got near the end of the series was kinda disappointing. After the mid way point of the anime the plot went downhill and I had no idea where they were going to go with the story. I was not a huge fan of what they did with Mumei "brother" to make him the main plot point in the ending.  The series was not bad but it wasn't good. It was a decent anime that could have been better. If it does have a second season I hope they go for more of a exploration type anime. Trying to figure out the origin of the Kabane, find a cure, find survivors, etc.

Ever since I was in my early teens I have been a fan of the zombie genre which started out as me playing all the Resident Evil games to reading all The Walking Dead comics. When I became a fan of anime one of my first thoughts was were there any good or decent zombie genre anime out there. There was really none out there other than ecchi girls vs zombies (High School of the Dead) or moe girls vs zombies (Gakkougurashi!) or as a theme for a single episode. I think Kabaneri is probably one of the only takes on the zombie genre inanime that can be taken as if you watching a proper zombie genre story unfold. However The story is not perfect its probably the best we got for a serious zombie anime for a wall. 


With all the negativity about the show people will probably think my current score is too positive however I don't factor in petty stuff like hype or rip-off accusations when I review something. I go into anime a lot with low expectations and I literally only heard of this show when it was coming out. Also I am pretty tired of Attack on Titan comparisons and this show is not the first I have seen with such accusations and I bet it won't be the last. If I where to be honest I would say it does have some elements when it comes to steam punk weapons and contraptions but that is pretty much it. 


The story takes place in an industrial revolution apocalyptic world where humanity resides in these places called stations.  The main story focuses on some humans trying to get from one of these stations to another while fending off these super zombies known as Kabane. Zombie genre stories go one of two ways. one being a story that focuses on what makes someone human where you have a group of weak or moderlately strong survivors trying to survive in best way available to them. The second you have an action series where a group of badasses kill zombies each day. Kabaneri is more of the latter when it comes to a zombie series.


The story has its high points and epic moments of pure Badassery that make the story fun. However the story is what is flawed with this series and is where it loses its points from me. I feel like the story was a bit rushed in the last few episodes. I feel like the series should have been twenty four episode since the pacing near the end seemed too fast. If the story did not feel as rushed in the end as it did I would have scored the series higher might have even given it a ten. 


The art in this series is absolutely amazing as WIT studio use similar high budget animation techniques like the ones they used in AOT to animate this series. The character designs are unique and makes them easily recognizable and not blend with the crowd of extras on the train and stations. The fights with the zombies known as the kabane are pretty epic when the fight look like a camera is paning around are characters as they take out the Kabane. There is some CGI used but it ain't horrible as it is really subtle making it hard to notice. If there was anything that truly carried this series it would be the art.


The only other thing that would be truly carrying this series is the music. The music in this series is absolutely amazing. The opening and ending themes are beautiful. In scenes such as fights or epic moments the music is like a gloss that makes those scenes shine better.  The japanese voices don't really pack much emotion other than Ikoma or Mumei in their worst moments. 


The characters in this series do feel shallow apart from Ikoma and Mumei who get the most development. I do like them but I felt the series could of developed the supporting cast a bit better. I really liked Ikoma as he pretty much was a rebellious badass throughout the series. My only problem was I think he might be a bit deaf as he shouted "MUMEI" alot.  Mumei who was a really badass character in the beginning did a bunch of 180s later on. We also had a villain but like other characters they too were shallow. 


Despite its problems I enjoyed Kabaneri. It was thrill ride but due to a few road bumps it lost its chance at being the perfect zombie genre anime.

Ok, before I get pitch forks out vying for my head, let me explain a little why my score is a 6. There are two reasons why: The music and the art. The amount of stills did bring the number down a bit but it was fluid for the most part and the music....I can't complain about it. It brought the mood up or down depending on what it was suppose to do in the situation. The voice acting was...pretty good for some of the characters. Others (especially the one who tried to sound American or British), didn't work at all. Now the two bigthings: the story and the characters. 


Characters: Ikoma was a strong MC for the most part with the exception with whining (especially in the beginning), and was an inventor with a reason to hate the Karabane. Mumei was amazing...for the first half and then she fell off the band wagon for pretty much the rest of the season which annoyed me to pieces.  Ayame was the biggest suprise to me ad who had, in my opinion, the most character development. She went from being an heiress with a carefree life without responsibility to being thrust into the leadership role. Sure, she had a couple of slips here and there but that's to be expected and the last couple episodes for her were amazing with how long she's come. Kurusu I didn't think I would like. In fact I hated him for the first few episodes. But then he grew on me and was terrified for him some episodes later. That normally doesn't happen. Biba for me was aggravating. He was just another typical villain which drove me nuts and wanted something different from him. Anything! The rest of the characters were pretty good. Takumi and Yukina were two that stood out. The twist with Takumi's character was surprising and was defiantly not expecting that. Yukina I just loved because of how bad ass she is. The rest were medicore and not very interesting (with a few more exceptions to the fellow steam smiths).  


Story: It's because of how medicore some of these characters are really hurt the story. And then there's the story itself. I'll be honest and say that the first couple episodes were amazing. It was a different concept with some elements of AoT (even that dreaded one arm joke by the end), but there were some deviations. But by the end the story was a slight train wreak and the finale was just rushed which ruined it a bit with how everything was set up. Not to mention there are plot holes that weren't properly addressed in the show. 


All in all, a half descent show if you want some mind numbing action and amazing music with pretty art.

Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress - Review
Characters - 7
Although not really anything we haven't seen, the central characters don't fail to impress. Due to their usually clear and singular motives they are easily understandable and thus drive the story forward; one knows what they want, but not how those intentions will play against each other.
The side characters lack meaning though, making them pretty uninteresting and generic. But if they are brushed off as side characters the main cast seems even more interesting.
Story - 8
This was rather interesting. Although seeming like a pretty generic adventure story at first, the plot twists with the introduction of Biba.His lack of logic or even madness makes it seem like he has further plans than the obvious. \n
At the end of episode 10 he has completely succeeded with anything so far, making big drama, or a new twist necessary for the hero to be able to win. This is achieved with the black blood, a big risk the hero has to take in order to win.\n
The last few scenes are also striking in that they bring a new twist to two characters; to Mumei, who ends Biba but doesn’t hate him for his actions, and thus differentiates herself from most generic characters; and to Biba, who’s last glimpse of humanity allows Ikoma to survive, not just achieve his goal.\n\n
Visuals - 9\n
High production quality and a fitting style make this show very visually appealing. Animation is smooth, and the character designs are interesting.\n\n
Sound Design - 9\n
Also a strong point of this series is the combination of situationally and emotionally fitting score as well as detail-rich ambience, which really ties the show together. The intro and credits song are also quite memorable.\n\n
Enjoyment - 9\n
This show has kept me interested with its unclear result. I didn't get invested in the characters, which made the idea of a complete failure after episode 10 so much more delightful. But even though it set itself considerably difficult goals as it moved on, it succeeded at resolving brilliantly. Thus it neither falls into the category 'boring', nor into 'interesting concept, horrible execution', which isn’t an easy feat.\n\n
Overall - 8\n
This has been a strong show and was definitely worth my time. Although starting off moderately generic, it started to get more interesting, and thus more complex to write. While watching this series I got scared more and more about it, because the chance for it’s failure continuously rose. So I was very relieved to see it turn out so brilliantly. This marvelous story, set of interesting character twists, and the production quality make this show a strong 8, maybe even more.

I'm not sure why I've been reading several negative reviews about Kabaneri - poorly developed characters, non-gripping storyline, AOT rip-off. I watched it again and I genuinely enjoyed it.
The art is top notch, the world building is good, I mean what can you do with 12 eps? You need more range to do expositions, but given the way they executed it, you'll be sucked into a post-apocalyptic Japan where steam trains are the main point of transportation, zombies roam freely, and there are unique individuals who are both human and zombie, all packed into an enjoyable steampunk adventure.
Not yet sold? Give the first episode atry, I am pretty sure you'd be asking for more.

(Maybe the mods can ask if I finished it *before* deleting my review? K thanks)
Pros: The art is very good, as well as the animation. They combined CG and 2D very well whenever you see a train. There's nothing wrong with the audio, but I don't exactly know what great audio is supposed to sound like. These things pull it up from a 1 to a 2, because I don't want to insult the art team, who most likely had nothing to do with the many issues with this series. Prepare for gore as well. Hair pulling gore, which for me is a plus.
Cons: Ifyou want bad writing, an unoriginal concept, trope filled, and often cookie cutter characters, on top of literally being a re-skinned version of attack on titan in almost every conceivable way: THIS IS THE SHOW FOR YOU!!


Now replacing the genuinely refreshing idea of giants with the most extremely abused enemy of all time: Zombies. Not just any zombies, but inconsistent ones, we're talking slow as a snail one second, to (not kidding) 100MPH full sprint, with no excuse. They never acknowledge this, they simply change speeds depending on plot convenience. It's extremely ridiculous and blatant.


Basically, if you *REALLY* like the attack on titan formula, this is for you. But you won't be getting anything new, no original characters, nothing you won't expect. If you haven't scene attack on titan, I think I'd recommend that over this. But that might be because I hadn't seen literally this exact story already, so it was actually original to me. As well as giants being more interesting than the hundredth zombie rendition.


We have the main character, dude who is sick of not being able to fight the force that trapping humanity behind walls, just like AOT. We have the extremely over powered female character, just like AOT. We have the guy that is always a dick to the main character, but of course is just trying to do the right thing, and of course is really a good guy, just like AOT (you get the idea, it's all like AOT). We also have the useless best friend character, who's special ability is yelling about how he's his friend.


I won't get into the spoilery reasons why this show is exactly like AOT, but take my damn word. I can't even... They *tried* to make this the same thing, they didn't even want to hide it.


Also, the token super powered girl wasn't as annoying in AOT, so there's that. That being said, in this show there's actually half a reason why she's so strong (even though she's still inexplicably stronger than someone else with this excuse), in AOT it's just a female power fantasy, with no excuse. So choose your poison.

As much as these types of shows inevitably gain popularity for obvious reasons, for me, Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress is one of those cases where I can't side with those that have enjoyed it.
The premise, in simpler terms, is basically "zombies with steampunk", but there definitely is more to it. For the most part, I like the world that has been set up. I should point out that I'm not big on the zombie genre. Despite that, I gave Kabaneri a chance, and unfortunately, I was a bit disappointed. It's not necessarily the plot, but I felt like there could have been more. Wecould have gotten more development with the world that's been created, however we get familiar plot elements and action sequences in favor of that.


With this type of story, characters are important. Survivors band together and get to know each other. We see that in Kabaneri, but not to the effect where I really care about them. They seem to be lacking something that makes me lose interest. There's hardly any chemistry that can be considered passable. The most story we get from a character is from the main heroine, and even then it feels like she's only there to be the cute girl that appears in most of the promotional stuff for the series.


The animation is the only great thing Kabaneri has to offer. Wit Studio always does a good job with their productions. The visuals alone made me want to know more about the universe. Despite what I said before, I still found the action sequences to be entertaining. The character designs are really interesting, and it turns out the original designer is also the original character designs for Gunbuster, which I thought was awesome.


In the end, the story Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress was a bit lackluster, but the animation and concept were just fine. Ever since the series premiered, many have been comparing this to Attack on Titan, another Wit Studio production. While showing similarities, I couldn't care either way. From the start, I knew there was going to be comparing, which is why I strayed from saying so. Kabaneri is an original concept, but there just might be some Attack on Titan influences in there. At any rate, I judged it as it's own thing, and even then, it's not that great.

I overall enjoyed the anime since it's mostly action and by the I mean that there isn't really a great plot to the anime but it isn't bad. It is about zombies, there's a lot of anime about zombies but this one seems unique and really interesting. 
I recommend you watch it, but what disappoints me that they could of done a way better job at making it by releasing more episodes since it could of improved on the story and made it longer.
I think I'm rating it too much, but it's been really enjoyable. I give it7.22/10

As said by some other reviewers on here, a lot of anime watchers have become incredibly picky, going as far as giving decent shows 3's and 2's because they've watched so much anime that it's nearly impossible for them to get an enjoyable experience from average shows. Koutetsujou no Kabaneri is definitely average in most ways. and very similar to Shingeki no Kyojin in every way especially the story, apocalypse level crisis with creatures out to destroy all of humanity, our only hope being a dude with a special ability to make him like the monsters we're fighting, and in the end it turns outthat we are still our own worst enemy, and there are a lot of walls. If you enjoyed Shingeki no Kyojin, like cool fight scenes, good artwork, a very nice soundtrack, and you aren't like these dummies asking for scientific realism in a steam punk zombie anime, you will probably like this. Cons are a couple annoying plot holes, average shonen characters, and the forced ignorance throughout the show may annoy the hell out of some people (it did me).

SO, this is a story set in a Steampunk-ish Edo era with human-monsters whose hearts glow & are something like a zombie-vampire hybrid who are smarter than your avg beast.

They constantly change what Kanabe (the monsters) can do & what the Kanaberi(monster-human hybrids) can do, making Kanaberi basically invincible.

I get that MC's are usually invincible, but the amt of times he's survived from these crazy situations is just crazy.


The enemy's objective is pointless & their leader has no real reason to have any followers, but they do anyways. 


REALLY, REALLY sucks too because this anime had SO much potential!

I've seen bad anime that deserved 1's & this is NOT it.

This is ok to a bad show in rating. It being a zombie show people of course die, not much of a spoiler at all. That is my first issue, I am fine with people dying but the way people die in this show has the pointlessly randomly ding. In other shows there is normally some building up to the death and you don't just have random character deaths. You may say this makes them more human, which I think I valid but it just makes me angry and constantly strained from fear of a random character death. If I had to compare this toanother anime it would be attack on titans, but slightly to slot worse (the main character is better, but that's just because the MC in AOT is the worst). Another thing is the main villain is kind of the worst as in he has no real strong motivation besides "screw you I'm angry". This makes me just hate him and makes me think he had to much screen time. He is also very shallow in everything he does and he also is a scumbag, which you might say is the point, but when I physically want to punch this man it is too effective. The MC probably doesn't have enough screen time or the screen time without him isn't well written enough for him not to be there. He makes a drastic 180 in his character at one point in the show for little to no reason and that made me mad. It started to get boring. The villain and his actions were cool if it wasn't taking place in this story and it had a different villain, same thing with the hero. It's as if the randomly took a villain and a hero and mixed them together expecting a good result. On there own they could be pretty strong but when mixed it just weakens them. This is one of the shows that makes me fear other shows will be similar because I kind of hate it. The main female character in the beginning seems strong and smart, but then you immediately learn she is actually just a toddler. The coolest part of this anime is the first 4 episodes. I would recommend watching those and then stopping in all honesty. The first 4 episodes are great then it just takes a turn for the worst. I am writing everything while watching episode 11 right now, so I can remember my feelings fresh. If my feeling change at all after finishing the last episode it will be written under this. On I think I get it now this anime has 2 to 3 arcs in my opinion. Those should have lasted 8-9 episodes the extra 3 dragged it out and made it very painful. If they added the ending of episode 11 in like episode 6 or 7 it would have been much better. This is why I wrote the part earlier before finishing it because the power of the last w episodes can swing a review, but I felt everything leading up to now has been so painful that i needed to talk about it from a raw point of view. It often pushes to narratives at once such as humans are dumb but then someone else preaches that humans are smart. Later in the episode you see someone doing something dumb but then later you see someone do something smart. Everything they do directly contradicts the morals being built or the ones that already exist. I figured out that the dialogue is lack luster but the actions scenes are very good and can actually manage to tell the story almost all on there own and the endless amounts of talking and silent staring and walking can basically all be skipped if you wanted to do that. The main character just verbatim said "what should I destroy next" this shows that he has no motivation except that he's board and want to destroy for no reason. That's not even elaborated on because the show keeps trying to show his "reason" down your throat. Everything that was a cool action movie like scene is now happening in one episode which is great but they should have spread it out instead of having nothing going on for about 6 episodes. Another note the soundtrack of this show saved it if it had no or a bad soundtrack I would have stopped episode 3. Just finished my opinions are all the same the ending was decent and that's about all.

"Wait, it's just Attack on Titan with zombies and steampunk trains. C'MON THAT'S JUST LAZY WRITING"
If I hadn't seen Attack on Titan, I'd probably think this show was more interesting and original, but since I have, it just seems like self-plagiarism. This review is basically going to cover why they're basically ripping of AoT.
=== STORY/CHARACTERS ===
The story and characters are exactly the same as the ones in AoT. You've got monsters (zombies, rather than titans in this case), that keep people boxed into small, walled in towns. Only 3 characters in the entire show can kill them, and everyone else just runs away in fear.
You'vegot your determined MC, who doesn't do much except yell about how he's going to kill all the Titans - wait, I mean zombies. He's half zombie himself, so everybody (except his friends) are afraid of him (and this fact is stated in the first episode, so there's not build up like Eren's titan reveal, after assuming he's dead).


You've got the MCs best friend, who's a geek, can't fight, and doesn't add a whole lot to the story (although, I do like this guy better than Armin. Armin's more of a whiny baby - even though he's a bit more developed).


The main female heroine isn't exactly Mikasa, but she's similar enough. Both are badasses that easily kill more monsters than everyone else in the show combined. Both have some dark past that explains their aforementioned baddassery. The only major difference, is Mikasa gives a crap about Eren, and this girl doesn't care about the MC (not that it's especially bad, it's just a difference).


And you've got everyone else who's too afraid to fight the monsters, and afraid of the MC because he's "one of them" and an "enemy of humanity", despite him saving everyone else a few dozen times.


Oh, and we've got a bit of Tokyo Ghoul in here as well, since the Kabaneri drink other peoples blood and can't function as regular members of society. So there's that.


Look man, I'm OK with a similar premise (post-apocalyptic survival in a world full of monsters), but you have to go somewhere interesting with it and have unique characters. These characters have less development (and less traits to begin with) than those in AoT. The backstory for any character can be summed up in a single sentence, the interesting side characters like Jean are non-existent. People's complete and utter fear of the Kabaneri's makes less sense (since they're not giant outta control Titans), and there doesn't seem to be a real end goal at the moment (other than to survive). Again, the writing is just lazy.


=== ART ===

I gotta give the art a high rating. The style is really cool, and all the scenes look great. I personally prefer the simpler art style in AoT, but dang, I'm impressed with the work that went into the art for this show. The only gripe I have is AoT's zipping around with hookshots led to *way* cooler looking fight scenes, that are yet to be reviled by anything else


=== SOUND ===

Sound is good: the opening and ending songs are catchy, and the soundtrack isn't distracting.


===========


Overall, I can't really rate this show higher than a 6 (maybe even a 5). If the characters or plot were different, I would probably bump this to an 8, but they just aren't, and there just isn't a lot of originality other than the world it takes place in. I'll watch it still, but I've just been a bit disappointed.

EdIt: After finishing this series, I feel the need to add on to this review.
First, let me establish that a score lower than a 5 in my book is something where I hated most of the characters with a passion, the story made me absolutely infuriated, I hated the art and sound, and the overall fun value I felt throughout was very very low, all ranging from 5 with to 1. I've never actually watched an anime I hated to that extend all of the way through because I don't like self torture, and I don't review anime I don't watch all of the waythrough because I'm not terrible. I don't really see why people bother with reviews that low, but I suppose I applaud those who take bullets for the rest of us by watching awful anime without getting paid for it or something. 


Anyway, looking back at the other reviewers it seems to me that a lot of people (especially those rated helpful) seem to be criticizing this series for trying to be too much like AOT, which is why I mentioned it in my original review. Looking back at the series I feel like this is unfair, as it puts a set of expectations onto Kabaneri that one really shouldn't go into watching it with. In reality, Kabaneri is similar to AOT only in basic premise. As far as writing and overall quality, this anime is nothing like AOT. By episode 4, it becomes apparent that the story is not very well written, but it is enjoyable due to the action and overall good fun vibes of it. Better than many, worse than a lot, and with enough modern touches to earn my respect. In short, it was good if you like that kind of thing, but still not something you would really remember even a year down the line and it's definitely not going to win awards for its writing. That being said, if you go in expecting it to be AOT (and you liked AOT), you're just going to be disappointed and probably infuriated. 


By the middle of the series, it becomes a bit of a frustrating mess as the show falls back into very overdone melodrama and stereotypes. It loses a lot of the qualities that made it enjoyable as annoying characters start to show up, and my opinion of Kabaneri suffered as a result. I dropped my story rating from a 7 (which was admittedly generous of me, but my rating in this category does tend to vary widely from genre to genre) to a 4, and the characters from an 8 (in respect of strong female presence) to a 4. 


That being said, I don't believe the unfortunate direction of the anime warrants a 3 or anything lower than a 5, really. The anime was an okay watch and progressively got worse, but never really hit a point where I came away absolutely hating it. In the end, as long as you like the premise of the show, go in without expecting high quality storytelling and characters, and just want to watch something for good fun, then this is a decent choice. If you hate absolutely anything without a good story or great characters, then you won't like Kabaneri and I don't recommend watching it/suggest dropping it. 


Original review follows:


A lot of people say this is basically the walking dead meets attack on titan. Which is true. But let me ask you this: why is that a bad thing? Why do people generally act like there is something inherently wrong about taking an idea and putting a new twist on it? I have news for you folks: anything is rarely new. If you think it is, you're probably just not old enough to remember what it ripped off. Ie, attack on titan is basically any given mecha mixed with battle star Galactica, with the admittedly pretty original twist of titans instead of battle suits. And the walking dead is literally just any zombie film, tv show, game, etc written by people who read The Road. And don't get me started about literally any given shonen anime. 


What should really matter is whether or not you like what they did with the idea. In this case, I do! I like the concept of the heroes becoming hybrids of the enemy. Call me pretentious, but I like to see writers handle the dichotomy between two warring factions with tricksteresque characters. It's why I love the Tokyo ghoul manga and Parasyte. 


The action in Kabaneri is enjoyable, and the characters are surprisingly refreshing. I especially appreciate the female representation. The main female lead is respectably bad ass, and she isn't just blatant fan service. Basically, she's mikasa. And I'm fine with that. We don't have enough women in anime for me to try and be picky about original character creation. And yes, there are cut outs, but even they have unexpected moments of pretty good writing. They also sometimes sprinkle in females in the background and into otherwise typically male roles, which is nice.


Basically, Kabaneri is an okay ride with decent characters and some very refreshing touches. The story seems fine to me, but I'm only 6 episodes in so that could quickly change. It's a solid 7-8 for me right now.

Sometimes people can compare an anime (Shingeki no Kyojin) to this show, but this well done by far. One day completed all episodes, first impressions: HELL YEAH. Overall, the animation, short stories of the characters, sceneries, and most of all, the two main characters are beyond..................................... can't find the right word but: magnificent. I truly hate when people compare this anime to another popular anime (Shingeki no Kyojin) and it truly put this anime as an underdog. And that's what makes this anime the underdog: the answers not answered right from the start. 
(This is to all those people who said: "YUCK", "WTF, hell no,not my precious "Shingeki no Kyojin", or "HA LAME" or "F**K this man.) You'll regret this once Shingeki no Kyojin concludes (for now but in the near future of course 😈) and consider this anime.


I can't tap into other people's taste but: "try it" because, at the end of the day, it won't hurt soo much.


Been a western rouge otaku (and first comment LUL)  but to my west people, watch it, and I promise you, you'll want more.


Highly hyped for the movie (hopefully it will come to the west) and hopefully the second season.


Recommended to all who seek action and a short story.

This show is such a blatant & shallow bandwagon-riding money-grab that I would have respected the creators more if they just acknowledged it and titled the show "Attack on Kabane -the maxim" or named the main character "Izumi Jaeger" or something.
If you're like me, you will find the "similarities" beyond stale by this point, but it's safe to say that those who enjoyed the tone and premise of those other shows (AoT and Parasyte [not to mention the many others with the same trope of humanity vs monster/oppressor where the MC somehow becomes infected or otherwise attains the monster's power but retains his humanity/sanity]) willenjoy this one. The show's pacing is satisfactory. The visuals are engaging and the tone is dark and suspenseful. Despite feeling like I've seen it all before, I still watched this show to completion. That said, the writing that serves as the show's foundation is lazy and derivative, and therefore I was not surprised to find the same absence of originality in every major plot development, every challenge/struggle/obstacle the characters faced (introspective and external), and every solution they chose to overcome them.



If you are the type to scrutinize the decision-making of characters, or simply the physical possibility of events in a show, and judge them by any realistic/logical standards, then this is not the show for you. If you can easily suspend your disbelief, and don't think much about the merits of characters' actions/decisions, then you at least satisfy what I would consider the prerequisite (in disposition) to enjoy a show like this.


MILD SPOILERS (from first episode of comparison shows Parasyte and Kabaneri)


One major thing that seemed just silly/ridiculous to me was how he stopped the spread of the infection. First of all he just straps some red-hot metal to his arm and then nails some bolts/strap into his chest. Not only does none of this make any goddamn sense in terms of stopping an infection from spreading, but how did he not black out from shock and pain? Assuming he's an insane badass and could stay coherent through the red hot metal alone, he would still just be curled up in the fetal position screaming bloody murder. Instead he takes it in stride "okay, just burned my arm down to the bone and that did nothing; time to fuckin' choke myself out." The only reason it works in parasyte is because it's a physical entity (the parasite/worm) that he is blocking with a tourniquet.


Unless this show somehow explains that the Kabane virus is actually a small parasitic organism that needs to reach the brain to survive past like 20 seconds, this scene will remain utter nonsense. How would choking yourself do anything? He doesn't even lose consciousness so it's not like it was even a strong/thorough choking. That also doesn't make sense... Sure is convenient how whatever industrial equipment it was that he used to choke himself showed restraint and choked him juuust right, rather than summarily squeezing the life out of him or--more likely--popping his head off like a grape. I'm pretty sure that when it comes to "tug of war," industrial metalworking machinery wins against flesh every time.


But hey since he bolted/nailed/burned/strapped all that arbitrary shit to himself, now the main character looks super kakkoii and unique. I like how nobody says anything about it either, apart from the Kabaneri girl addressing his choker. "Hey why does that guy have a bunch of shit bolted to himself?" "Umm do you not see how cool it looks?"


---------------------------


Beyond that, be prepared for a main (human) antagonist who seems completely level-headed and rational when the story needs him to be, and then tosses reason out the window and murders hundreds if not thousands of innocent people over a grudge he held against one person from a decade ago. Never mind that humanity is at risk of extinction, he and all of his soldiers are apparently fine with slaughtering innocent women and children in droves because the shogun deserted them on the battlefield. If you watched the show you know what part I'm referring to, and it was also necessary for them to turn Mumei into an unthinking sap for this plot point as well. Not one of the soldiers or Mumei is like "hey wait maybe this dude is a bad guy after all, I mean he's constantly spouting shit about how the weak don't deserve to live but he was a child at one point too right? Naah never mind it's best if we just don't think about anything and continue following the lead of an absolutely insane person hypocrite.

Boy, this show… 
What made me want to watch this anime was the fact that it was made by the same company that made Attack on Titan, a show that I greatly enjoyed, Wit Studio. I knew it was going to be similar, but I didn’t know it was actually Attack on Titan but with Zambies, oooooo spooky... The story was the exact same as Attack on Titan… Replace the survey corps’ horses with a train, the different walls with train station and the Titans into zombies and there you go, you have Kabaneri of the iron fortress. The art and the music was prettymuch the only best things of the anime. The art was clean, dark and very fitting for the story of the anime. The sound was clean the voice actors did a good job and frankly, the music was pretty decent. The characters were cliché as hell like a wimp turned badass, a badass girl and a dumb best friend. I actually enjoyed the show but let’s be honest it’s just an attack on titan copy and paste.\n

Where to start? 
Let's beginn with with the Art and Sound. If this anime has something to go for it are this two things. Sound is amazing. Maybe I am a bit biased because I just love those EGOIST songs. Anyway. I did enjoy it. 
Art as well. Lot of details and it fits the this steam punk style. What I don't like is the look of the characters. I don't know but they don't really seem to fit in. Don't get me wrong, they still look good but they don't go with the background. 
How should I put it? Do you know this oldcartoons from the 80-90s? You could always tell which rock etc was the rock something is going to happen with in the next shot. It just stand out. Here I do have the same feeling. Maybe make them less shiny next time.  \n\n
Then story. Well I do like the idea of it. I mean if you can go with the background story of Attack on Titans you can go with this. Instead of Titans you have some kind of Zombies and people are also living behind walls. So far so good. \n
Now some parts which could include some SPOILERS but I try to keep it spoiler free. \n
The first episodes I did enjoy. Especially Miumei's first fight. It was indeed rly cool and reminded me to the 3D gear action of AoT. Also the actions the characters did, seemed reasonable. \n
But with episode 5/6 this changed. Here the authors probably thought normal zombies are not enough, we need something bigger. And so the black smoke is introduced. \n
From this point on it gets stupid and made up. It just does not feel right. In episode 5 a short glimpse at something what could be a tank turret. But it doesn't get further attention. In e6 when the crew is rescuing Miumei and Ikoma. They found this turret and somehow put it on the train off screen. Hey the train has a gun now and it is useful to destroy the shadow. How could they just cruise around with the train and install the turret when before everything was filled with Zombies? Who cares!\n
And stuff like this keeps happening till the end. It just feels stupid. Miumies actions kill thousands in the last episodes. But noone really cares. Oh hi Miumie, glad you are back. Your actions killed thousands? Doesn't matter you are still the cute girl. \n
It just feels mehhh.\n\n
And so do the characters. I gave a damn about them and I did not like them. Ok, I did somehow liked one character, but he dies. But even here I didn't really felt sad. \n\n
All in all I am giving this a 6. If it would be possible I would giving it a 6,5 but it isn't. Therefore 6 it is. \n
It is an OK anime to watch, but if you expect an Attack on Titan Killer like some did when this anime was introduced you will get disappointed.

The art in this show was beautiful, there of coarse were some dips in the animation quality but even then the show looked great. The animation was smooth, and the pallet used for the show looked very nice. the fight scenes looked great, and the CGI used in parts of the show was alright. The character designs were great, every design was distinct from one another. the show had recurring background characters that you could recognise even if they weren't important, which i thought was a nice touch to the show. The story was very predictable, there was no twists or surprises, everything you thinkwill happen will probably happen. The character interactions for the earlier half of the show are enjoyable to watch. The only character that gets any sort of arc or development is the main character. The villain also got some backstory but it really did nothing to really explain or justify his actions, he was poorly written and obviously just there because the show needed a final villain for the end. The show is enjoyable but for the most part it's only because of the art/animation, and the action. I would give it a 6.5 overall, but since i can only give scores with round numbers i'll be generous and give it a 7 because I did enjoy the show when i watched it.

REVIEW WITH NO SPOILERS!!
First of all, this was an anime I was not expecting much. Just watched it because, I hadn´t really anything more to watch :p
But It chocked me how awesome it can be. You will need to love Drama ( a lot), zombies (kabanes) and something more, which cannot be told because of spoilers! I can relate It with The Walking Dead, but with a little diference, zombies here are nuts!!! Obviously, it isnt as awesome as TWD, but It can really give you a good time.
--STORY-- (9)
Story is great! You are brought in the middle of the industrial revolution, Japan is filledwith kabanes (probably the whole world, but thats not told in the anime). The only way to kill this kabanes is by destroying their hard heart. But if you get bitten, you are basicaly gonna turn! The story is arround a crew compoused by some samurais, a women that commands the crew, our protagonist and a girl, who is basicaly the pair of our man!

Our protagonist is a blacksmith, and he as the ability to build weapons, that can destroy those kabane's hearts.

Finally, the ending is awesome, I can guarantee, a little bit cliche, but it gets what we want in the end!!


--Art-- (8)


Well, I know nothing about Art and Graphic Desing, really, but I enjoyed the Steam Theme where the anime is built on, because of the industrial revolution. Nothing that fascinate me, but oh well, it was Very Good.


--Sound-- (7)


Sound is a taste thing. Either you love it, or you just hate it.


The oppening is acceptable, not the best thing of the world, but yeah, not bad.

Through out the anime, it really blends in with the anime theme, the last scene really give the feelings!!!!


--Character-- (9)


This is best of that anime. The characters. Oh man, I Love every single on of them, even the villains.


Our protagonist is a very cliche one, but, he really grows through out the anime. We watch him being a coward in the beggining, really not messing with anyone. And then he starts to change, because of an event on his life (which I cannot tell, or it would be a spoiler :p). He ends up being a complete badass, and taking the "prize" home!!


Our villain, oh man, our villain. His name is Biba, I can compare him with Negan from TWD. He loves hurting people, and has a statement in his life: Weak must die, the strong live on. I can't say it, but he impacts the last episodes as hell, he was really who made the story to me.


--Overall-- (9)


I give it a 9. Not perfect, it would be perfect if It had a awesome soundtrack, but apart from that, it really was a good anime.


Hope you enjoyed this fast review!


First review by the way!!! :p

So what do we have here? Some zombies, some hot chicks and some badass, to save the world determined dude, who is coincidentally very special. Sounds familiar doesn't it? To summer it up real quick: this anime is your everyday action with pretty lollies, baddas MC, great flashy fight scenes and overall a lot of prettiness. Story is accordingly simple and shaped way so it can show off the animation(it occasionally doesn't bother to make sense).
You simply watch this anime with eyes only. Brain is not really needed.

-Special pretty girl to be MC's waifu? check (got both lolly and normalgirl!!)\n
-Constant threat of danger from a special virus? check\n
Random thought: This is where I began to think that I'm writing about Black Bullet.\n
-Vicious, vicious villain? -check and set we are!\n
Art:9\n
Like, it's like sooo pretttttyyyyy! Seriously though, the art is amazing. When shit goes down color tone gets darker, when everyone is happy the screen smiles at you. It simply tells the tale better than the tale does.\n
Sound:5\n
I didn't really feel any thrill and I didn't ahte it neither.\n
