The first two episodes of this show had me hooked.. and then I kept watching. With every episode after 2, I felt the show getting worse and worse. Mumei went from being a pretty awesome and mysterious character to the cause of almost literally every single problem in the entire series. To top it off, no one seems to even acknowledge that what they are going through is because of her consistently making stupid choices. The main character seems to always talk by yelling, and it is hard to find scenes were he isn't talking in a raised voice, it was just something that irritatedme personally. The one thing I did like about this show was how well animated it was, there's a lot to see in the character animations. It is not a terrible show and I did enjoy parts of it, most of my issues lie with the characters themselves, and if you don't mind shallow characters this show can be great.

This anime possesses what is probably my favorite soundtrack to date. The music is, in my opinion, the best aspect of this show and it did wonders for setting the mood and building tension where appropriate. The story itself was fine, a bit reminiscent of other popular anime (Attack on Titan) but with enough of its own originality to hold my interest. It had a large cast of incredibly diverse characters with compelling relationships and interactions, all done in a unique art style. It was enjoyable, to say the least, although not mind-blowing. I wished some of the action scenes were a bit flashier. WhenMumei fought with her bladed sandals in the first episode I loved it, and I wished those unusual weapons were used in more episodes.

When you begin Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress it quickly becomes evident that a lot of ideas were borrowed from Attack of Titan. The best form of flattery is imitation, no? Look at how many series in the late 90s and early 2000s borrowed from Neon Genesis Evangelion (i.e. Rahxephon, Fafner, or Bokurano).
The above being said, Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress is a competent anime. I don't think the story is nearly as developed as say Attack on Titan, but remember Attack on Titan has a manga to pull source material from and Kabaneri is an original anime series. Also in the twelve episodes Kabaneriwas given there was only so much time to tell a full story. I do hope that the second season announced will do more to develop an intriguing plot.\n
As for the show's design though, wow. The details in the scenery and backgrounds are way impressive, and as a personal preference I really dig the mashup of steampunk, post-apocalyptic, and traditional Japanese aesthetic. I just find it cool. The character design and animation by Wit Studio are very pleasing to the eye. The characters are just interesting enough to keep watching from episode to episode, but I'd really like to see more development of them in the future season. I love good character development and I don't think we were really able to see substantial growth and change in our characters.\n
All my criticisms aside, I watched through the twelve episodes quickly because this show was very entertaining. Great animation, world design, and action kept me engaged. Personally I think a good analogy for this series is that it's like a popcorn action flick. It's just fun entertainment and nothing too serious. That being said, I think the premise that has been established has a lot of potential and I am excited to see what happens with the second season.

I came in with quite high hopes but left a little bit disappointed. No spoiler review. 
Here is what I liked:
- The world and setting. The feudal Japan mixed in with the threat of the kabanes was very interesting. 
- The Animation. Very nice to watch and every frame had something going on in it: good on the eyes. 
- The story was good as well, with a mostly unexpected twist at the end.
- The ending was satisfying although i do have my gripes with it. 
- I loved some of the less important characters. I really liked the relationship between kurusu and ayame asit ended up giving a comedic touch to the series. I wish they had given more development to the rest of the crew, especially the english-japanese speaking mechanic who i don't even remember the name of due to lack of character development. But whatever  I understand they only had 12 episodes.\n
Here is what i disliked:\n
- Ikoma's voice got on my nerves especially when he's screaming and it cracks up. I get that it is fitting but this being my review and all.... goddamn. \n
- I felt like the characters were cliche, mumei in particular. The relationship between mumei and ikoma and how it unfolded was quite predictable and nothing new which is a big no no from me considering it is a focal point in the whole series. \n
- SPOLIER ALERT\n
I know i said this was a spoiler-free review but I have to in order to get my point across here.\n
So I KNEW Ikoma wasnt going to die the moment he was thrown off the train and I KNEW he wasnt going to die at the end the moment he went through his whole transformation thing. Therefore, the fact that, despite what he was sure of, Ikoma survived after all was not surprising to me. However, the fact that Biba saved him was an interesting and unexpected twist so I'll give them that.\n

This show could have been something good. It had everything that made Attack on Titan good in the mix but it got the proportions wrong. It's like using baking soda when baking powder is needed. 
There was a decent world built, with decent characters that could have been expanded and evolved. The possibility of a good villain that no one knew about what available. 
Instead you got a decent world that ended up amounting to "This is how it is and A:We like this world, let's protect it. B: We should destroy this world and everyone in it for reasons!". 
The decent characters never gotexpanded and never developed. They had a type and stuck to it entirely. It was like playing GEN1 pokemon and mashing B during evolution. \n\n
The villain? Guy with daddy issues. That's it. Daddy was mean to him once and decided to destroy the world. Because, you know, that's a logical thing to do. And bad guys men? They were... dunno. Some were bad and some weren't? Maybe?\n\n
Listen, if you have nothing to watch or just want to watch something bad, here's your show.

Given the plethora of negative reviews, it's fairly easy to dismiss this anime as one of the worst animes of all time. Scroll after scroll, I see countless reviews giving 2s and 3s, ripping the show into pieces. What many of the other reviews do a fantastic job is diving deep into the root of the problems of this show and most of their complaints and concerns are justified. The characters are quite undeveloped and their actions seem unexplainable. The plot turned into quite the shitshow by the end and the amount of random asspulls started looking like naruto for a moment. But looking beyondthose negatives, I still feel like the show does a couple things well that warrant at least the 3 episode rule. 


Instead of typing deep analysis on why this show fails (you can just read the other reviews), I want to first explain why this show is getting such unwarranted negative press and then hopefully convince you that this show is still worth watching.


------ ------------------------Why the negative press -----------------------------


1. Overhype: Koutetsujou no Kabaneri was probably one of the most hyped up animes of all time. The directors and creators of both Attack on Titan and Code Geass teamed up to make a an anime original. With such a large cast and multiple infamous studios behind the show, it seemed like a recipe for success. Once the show aired the first episode, the hype only continued. The golden 4 episodes (something I will touch upon later) aka the first 4 episodes established a story and cast of characters that were unique. People had expectations of a Attack on Titan remix but were quickly dispelled as the story had enough nuances to establish a ground for itself. Once the plot started to deteriorate so did the hype. By not living up to the viewers' expectations of what could have been the next biggest anime of all time, people began trashing it and dismissing it. Everything that wasn't perfect was picked on and simply hung out to dry. The disappointment of having so much potential and throwing it away, angered many viewers which prompted them to tarnish the show's whole reputation. Had the anime not gotten as much hype as it did, I believe that most people would have simply given it quite an average or good rating and not such a low one. 


2. Band Wagoning: As more and more people began disliking it and expressing those sentiments, more people followed. Koutetsujou no Kabaneri became the laughing stock of the anime community. In fact, if you continued to openly like it, other users would eagerly jump at the chance to attack your opinions. Granted, the anime did deteriorate in pretty much all of the literary elements that create a cohesive story. However, many people failed in making an unbiased review. Furthermore, the band wagoning effect straight up hyperboled many of the flaws. Every show has its flaws and there are plenty, and I mean PLENTY of worse shows than Koutetsujou. If we were to simply compare this show to another show on an equal myanimelist level and rating, this show would be disproportionately more hated. 


------ -------------------------Why watch this show -------------------------------


1. The music: Sawano is a god. I'm not sure what else there is to say. Created by the same composer as Attack on Titan, Nanatsu no Taizai, Owari no Seraph, the music is quite simply amazing. I've listened to the main theme countless of times and of course it has the Sawano drop. Probably one of the few aspects this anime truly excels at, the music is definitely worth exploring even if you dislike the anime


2. The golden 4 episodes: As I said earlier, the golden 4 episodes or the first 4 episodes are probably one of the strongest starts in a show I've seen to this day. In fact, I think if you really wanted to leave on a good note, I would just watch to episode 4 and stop there (the end of episode 4 is actually somewhat conclusive). Why is this the case? Given the concerns about a copycat of Attack on Titan, Koutetsujou needed to establish its uniqueness and what it had to offer. It did a fantastic job creating a plot and world different from AoT despite having a very similar premise (humans going extinct from unknown species). Although there were clearly some homages to Attack on Titan especially in the directing and scenes, each episode delivered something new which furthered the hype and intensity. The quick pace and tone the anime immediately captured the viewer's attention. In fact, I would go so far as to argue that the first episode of Koutetsujou no Kabaneri is one of the best pilot episodes of all time. Not only did it hook me with the premise and intriguing characters, the directing, art/animation and sound were absolutely spot on. Just watch it and see if you like it. I can guarantee you will. 


3. Enjoyment: I think one of the biggest thing the anime community fails occasionally and especially in this case is looking at  anime too critically. For me, one of the ways I can enjoy various animes is simply by turning off my brain and taking it at face value. I know there are huge gaping flaws but I can still dismiss them and enjoy the show for what it is. And that's not to say that looking at it critically is wrong at all. In fact, it is vital for a successful show to have good plot and character development as well as the sheer enjoyment factor. However, when you look at the show in only that analytical lense, you fall into the trap of thinking that everything it does is horrible. If you can kick back and watch the show without thinking too much about it, I think you can find some sort of enjoyment.


Overall I think this show has something unique to offer enough to warrant a watch. The superb soundtrack coupled with the extremely strong first 4 episodes and interesting premise was enough to keep me hooked. Yes there are flaws and yes they are noticeable. But, if you can look past it and simply enjoy it for what it is, I think the 7.5 user base rating is pretty accurate despite the plentiful 2s and 3s.

HOP ON BOARD THE 2016 HYPE TRAIN. WATCH THIS SHOW DE-RAIL INTO THE TRAINWRECK THAT IT IS. This show went downhill super fast. It could have had some potential but they just decided to turn it into a cheesier version of Attack on Titan.
Pros:
-Very nice art in terms of the setting/feels ghibli-esque (Princess Mononoke vibe) 
Cons:
-most predictable and generic story ever (grumpy guy meets girl, becomes friends with her, goes into rage mode and defeats bad guy, the end)
-lame characters 
-Bunch of things went unexplained
Verdict: If you are in middle school you might enjoy this anime. If you like anime that has slightly more depthand isn't just a cheesy zombie fest then stay far far away.

To simply put,the anime community's expectation is really complicated.Even if someone creates just the perfect anime that "everyone" is looking for,there will be no doubt that something or someone will completely ruin it.Perhaps sometimes,it's not just that particular something or someone to blame.Sometimes,it's just how things are.
Yes,I'm talking about once "most anticipated" Koutetsujou no Kabaneri,the anime that EVERYONE thought of looking like the clone of Shingeki no Kyoujin. And I don't blame the viewers,because I thought the same too.And it was my motivation to continue to watch it in the first place. But...
Story:
The was decent.And I mean flat-out decent.It's a overly "simple" straight linear progression.It introduced to the problem,gave a gradual slope rise,introduced the villain,jumps to the climax where the entire beginner plot turned upside down(maybe tried to create a "holy shit!" type of failed excitement),then it progresses down the slope very fast and ends up with the villain dead and everyone lives "happily ever after."Hey don't get me wrong,I have no problem with positive endings.But...you know...this is too common,lol. And it is nowhere close to the twist and turns and mystery of Shingeki no Kyoujin.Please don't compare them anymore.


Art:

The art style was pretty unique.It was not anywhere close to Shingeki no Kyoujin.It was not overly detailed.But the scenes are fluent the visual effects are exciting to look at.It did give off a apocalyptic theme with dark colors.


Sound:

The music and soundtrack were fair and it blended in with the scenes.They were quite noticeable.


Character:

The character info and development was a disappointment to me.They overly summarized the character's personality,mentality and history.There were many characters who are left unknown even though they were connected to the main characters. They just picked out the most notable characteristics of the characters and only spent time on that,which made the story too simple to watch and confusing regarding how or why the characters got involved with the main  story.


Enjoyment and overall:

I tried to keep the review short,but I know it's still a bit long.But I had a lot to say about this series.Honestly,when Biba was introduced and the entire story turned to "I want to kill my father because REVENGE!" plot,I totally started to hate it.I even wanted to quit it if it wasn't for only 12 episodes.I enjoyed the story in the beginning and had high hopes for it.But toward the end,I didn't like it as much.It was too common,too simple,too strightforward and not at all like Shingeki no Kyoujin.I wish they made the story more like that.But this anime is just like that - really pretty outer look, but dumb inside.

On initial view you might be thinking, oh great another post-apocalyptic-zombie-theme piece of media sandwich. You might not be wrong in thinking that but Koutetsujou no Kanbaneri is a very tasty sandwich.
The visuals and soundtrack are excellent. They hype you up for the key moments and scenes. They make you feel downward spiral when the characters are suffering. The characters are well projected with good writing with distinct personalities although lacking sophistication. 
The main characters of the show are Ikoma and Mumei. Both characters are interesting in their own rights and satisfying to watch as you follow through their own story-lines. The story progression isnatural as they blend the overarching plot with character development almost seamlessly. 


The story follows a group of refugees that lost their home to the Kabane, As the plot develops, the story shows the conflicts and struggles that one might face when a community is evicted from their land. Both leadership and conflict inciters appears while Ikoma and Mumei tries to find their roles in the group as outsiders (and Kabaneri). 


But don’t expect deep conversations or revelations from the show, like you might expect from a complex seinen anime. Because at it’s core, this is an action eye feast for those who enjoy good combat animation and sequences. 


But lacking depth does not mean it lacks elegance. The show often takes a moment to show you the land/cityscapes,  Showcasing the scale of the enormous beautiful world that they have build for these characters.  


And beneath all the limbs and guts flying,the show tackles many uncomfortable questions we do not face commonly as a society. Like one of which is, when face with a threat that might come from within, do we let fear us break apart or do we fight together in unity?


Overall, despite it’s overly used theme, the show is most definitely worth the watch for all it’s beautiful aesthetics and decapitating zombie glory.

READ FIRST: This anime is by the same director and studio that made Attack on Titan. If you loved AOT, and HAVE NOT seen much anime besides this, you will likely really enjoy Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress. 
If, like me, Attack on Titan was the crossover you needed to branch East to West and you have since seen piles of anime with each subsequent show raising the bar of what you thought was "good", then read on.  
Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress is a very particular kind of bad. Its not unlike what happens in the U.S. whenever Michael Bay touches something: astory that almost forces its audience into stupidity in order to accept it. Interestingly, the anime history of director Tetsurō Araki features some of my most disliked and heavily criticized pieces. An astounding amount of anime I personally dislike for being "too Western" in its writing and directing fall under this directors scope. 


Attack on Titan, as mentioned, was one of the first anime that really sucked me in, particularly because it was so unlike most other anime. I have now come to see this as a mostly bad and aggravating thing, something of a Western/Shakespearean tinge on writing that I wish to escape. This kind of writing has four essential elements: 1. unnatural or forced tragedy for tragedy's sake 2. plots that advance strictly due to a lack of communication or "if only he/she would listen" cliche's and 3. stories written around scenes/images/characters. 4. A belief that media should portray "reality" (i.e. directors idea of reality) which is usually gritty, gut-wrenching, and "realistic" (versus noble, virtuous, or portraying characters and the world in an idealistic way = almost all other anime) 


Spoilers ahead (tried to keep them minima/vague):


Kabaneri is rife with all of these Western downfalls. I thought, at one point, that if the author had been 14 and American this show would have been much more acceptable; but no, not the case. The amount of forced, ex machina tragedy is offensive to the viewer because it demands them to be stupid; it is utterly unbelievable and ham-fisted. Next, a significant amount of the plot happens because of miscommunication and people not believing or listening to obviously critical information. Third, after finishing this show, its hard not to think that the author simply had a drawing of Ikoma and decided to build an lazy story for the character that would let the author gush all his chunibyo out; cool but completely ambiguous fight scenes, an mc transformation, superpower and bandages, steam-punk crap, a cape for some reason, hair changing color to represent upgrade, a power that threatens to overcome the character/must be unleashed, etc. etc. etc. Its all here. Lastly, the unnecessarily gut-wrenching awfulness of the villain where terrible things happen just so that the author, somewhere, can look an go "haha, see how horrified they are!? Yeah, nice!!". 


Lets not discard the technical squabbles either (it should be noted, I think this show would have benefitted greatly from 24 episodes). Right off the bat, Ikoma becomes the cliche-est of cliche main characters in a sequence so non-sensical and laughable that I could hardly understand it. Nothing about what he does in the first episode makes any sense, and when he starts stapling steam-punk crap to himself for no reason, its pretty hard to take seriously. Almost no backstory is given at all for the Kabane or why anything is the way it is. Lets look at some questions right off the top:


1. What are the Kabane's actual abilities? Are they slow or fast? In one scene they are your classic zombie and can be easily slowed down with limb or head damage. In the next scene they are all but invincible, can run at superhuman speed, and can throw themselves so hard they can break through steel armor plating. Are they intelligent? Why can some fight and others cant? Why is it that any time a horde of them appears in the tens of thousands, the mc's only have to kill about 20 for everyone to be fine? What is the virus? Are the humans trapped inside still alive somehow? The existence of the Kabaneri would lead one to believe so, in which case they really are killing people still (not to mention what is learned at the end about the different "serums"). 


2. What are the Kabane? Where did they come from? Is it some dumb T-Virus kind of thing? Why do they attack humans? How, on earth, do their hearts become like steel or coated with steel or whatever? Why does this happen? I'm pretty sure it takes highly advanced steel to stop a bullet, the body has a minimal amount of iron in it, but even if all the body's metals were concentrated, I have a hard time believing it would form anything close to a bullet proof barrier around the heart. 


3. What are the Kabaneri's actual abilities? In one scene Ikoma can destroy everything and everyone and take almost unlimited damage, much more-so with Mumei. In the next scene a few punches from some guy (along with Mr. Plot ex Machina) renders him completely useless. Is he strong or not? Is he fast or not? Mumei seems to be able to jump hundreds of feet and land from any height without damage - how does physical contact or impact from a person hurt them at all? Additionally, does Ikoma's gun only work up close? It seems like it can also work from a distance, so why does he never use it at a distance when it would literally solve everything? Why does he only become weak when having literally any of his previously seen abilities would change everything? (Bad writing being the elephant in the room here) 


3. What on earth is Biba's plan? Get revenge by killing everyone? Where is he going to go afterward? What people does he intend to live with? Did he really not have the firepower to get revenge without 'scorching the earth'? His plan makes no sense. 


4. By the end I was wishing Kaneki from Tokyou Ghoul would just show up and kill everyone. Given the amount of 'sharing' happening regarding the Kabaneri and ghouls, it would be more believable that Kaneki existed in this world than the story we are left with. 


5. Where is anyone getting any of their resources for everything??? And how do any of their weapons work? Why is the steel of the Kabane's heart stronger than other steel? How on earth can it be forged into the human's weapons. That would require removing its strength, using tools strong enough to shape the still strong (but weakened/annealed) steel, then the knowledge and skill to re-forge it!!!!!!!!!! If Ikoma could do all of that in an instant, then he could have also determined what the composition of the steel was and how to make it. Of course, its probably made from some kind of magical-asteroid steel - which, again, somehow is special but also found in the body. You can see how quickly it all becomes ridiculous, and not in the fun, over-the-top way. There was an idea here, and the laziest possible story was created to meet all the requirements of the idea so it could happen. 


I'll stop here for now, there is so, so much left that could be ripped up (hardly touched on the characters). A main point is this, AoT had a certain charm because the author worked with an friend in engineering to make his mechanisms as believable as possible; It's very clear this author didn't, and it really, really shows. In fact, one of the few reasons I found AoT's tragedy and drama acceptable at all was because of the attention to detail and believability of it; despite its Western tendencies for annoying writing, it pulled something interesting off. This show is a classic example of "less than the sum of its parts", a sort of anti-gestalt. It needs to be picked apart, it needs to be chided, and it needs a lot of it; directors and authors like this need to know when their work is lazy and dumb. Otherwise, it becomes popular and sells well because its pretty or has tons of hype and the directors & authors think people want more. Otherwise, we get Michael Bay's all over the place and the director/writer-kabane start to swarm, seeking to feed of the wallets of consumers drawn in by hype and shiny things.

Are you familiar with something related to human eater? I bet you are. As anime lovers, people will not be surprised to hear something like that. Tokyo Ghoul and Attack on Titan as the examples of man eater. So does the Kabaneri. The differences are, Kabaneri’s series man eater is not humanoid species, Kabane is another species. Those humans who got infected mysterious virus become Kabane. And also, Kabaneri’s series is about survival. Survival of mankind who left in the world from Kabane’s attacks (quite different from Tokyo Ghoul). To this state of storyline, I declare, from my opinion, it’s not something new even ifthe source of story is stated original. It’s post-apocalypse anime caused by Kabane’s  attacks.


Ikoma, is a normal human before he is bitten by Kabane. He successfully stops the spread of the virus from his infected arm on himself. Later on he finds out that the success to stop the virus in his body doesn't mean he is negative (from being a Kabane). Yeah, this is where our hero begins his story, he is a half-human and half-Kabane, a Kabaneri. His first obstacle is to make others believe that he won't going insane like Kabanes. But, a hybrid still a hybrid, he has genes of a Kabane, makes him half of it. His journey starts off. He and the people in his area, is on survival train to reach a safe shelter far away. Along the way, they will find many Kabanes head off.


​

I mentioned above, this series was reassuring for me, and even made me curious which is not often for me to get attached to something-like Kabaneri’s series (because the CGI animation). Yep! The graphics there mostly 2D, but got CGI animation in it. Not too much, sadly, not appealing either. Nicely, they can bring the terrible fact of countless deaths and horror vibes with the visualization aside from CGI animation. I don’t know whether the animation being lack of colours intensity or lack of sharpness that made the characters somehow look ungraceful. Back to the ‘reassuring issue’, indeed it was convincing “at first.” The story progress for the halfway of whole show was exciting, far from dull improvement. After few episodes in which the Kabane apocalypse isn’t the real threat, that was when I wanted to drop this series for sure. The political spice stirs the whole purpose of me watching the show, of being so engaging by its survival and journey to get to safe place, into a show of a noble madman makes use of Kabane into political/personal grudge thingy. This turn-over can’t be worse.



The characters development had slow improvement, feels like nothing at all even if so many occurrences and feelings there; the frightfulness, will to survive, optimism, friendship, desire to help, guide the main characters to be more adaptable and dependable to fight the Kabane. Not only their strength, but also kindness in their hearts. The relaxing moments tuck as the characters take their rest for fighting Kabane. I think its purpose to show that even in hard time there must be time to relax awhile, and to deepen their relationship which is not interfered by Kabanes. Unfortunately, I think it didn’t fit well. Maybe if they put it into different way, it will work better.


The OP and ED have done by EGOIST and Aimer with chelly (EGOIST), these names aren't new to you.  "KABANERI OF THE IRON FORTRESS" by EGOIST is the OP theme for Kabaneri series. Personally, EGOIST's works do not fit my taste but I do have several works from them that I keep on my playlist. But this one, absolutely no for me. The OP sounds like it tries to give you something dreadful about the show, about how frustrating fighting never-ending Kabanes and survive in a shelter. So dark and full of sadness. Not because of its terror vibe, but the music itself I can't barely enjoy. Aimer with chelly (EGOIST) "ninelie" is the ED theme. Better than OP a bit. The insert songs are quite good along the show.



Such a turn-over brought down my excitement to watch this. Well, 6.5 for its anti-climax ending.

Pros: Entertaining anime (at first), it successfuly got the tension and horror.

Cons: It's unlikely to be original because I can feel it is so similar with some other series, and damn minus for its turn-over. So bye.

I didn't have high hopes for this show, and I think that's why I actually sort of enjoyed it. Does it have a beautifully crafted, original, well-developed storyline? No, it's about steampunk zombies. Does it have some really cool action scenes? Yes. If you're looking for a mindless action show, something like Attack on Titan (because the two shows have only been compared like, a million times), you might want to give Kabaneri a try.
The characters aren't even remotely interesting, and neither is the story. I did like that it had a happy ending, though. To me, there wasn't too much missing from the finale,and I wouldn't mind if it never got a second season. \n
The art is fantastic, I expect no less from 2016 yet I was pretty impressed. The voice acting, for the most part, isn't really worth mentioning but I think Hatanaka Tasuku did a pretty good job as Ikoma. He has an interesting voice, it's slightly different from the typical shounen hero so it caught my attention.\n
Overall, KnK isn't entirely terrible, but it's definitely not worth any more than the few hours it takes to watch 12 episodes.

Overall an effective way to kill some time
Koutetsujou no Kabaneri revolves around a boy named Ikoma who works as a mechanic of some sort in a settlement surrounded by big walls. Outside the walls are monsters called Kabane, former humans who were infected with a virus that turns them into man/eating zombies with a stee-like mutation that guard their hearts. Amongst the people in his settlement, Ikoma is the only one who seems to realize that the Kabane are infectees, while the rest of the people believe it to be a curse of some sort. When the kabane attack and Ikoma is bitten, he managesto halt his change into a Kabane, turning into a Kabaneri: Abeing inbetween huan and Kabane. Along with another Kabaneri, Mumei, he guards the koutetsujou ( a train ) on it's way to the capital where the people of his hometown look for shelter.     

So far the synopsis


STORY 4

As far as the story goes, Koutetsujou disappoints heavily. The zombie-theme is not especially new to begin with ( albeit anime has not yet sen much zombie-oriented series ), and Attack on Titan explored it in a new light, so studio Wit must have felt like they needed to exceed themselves and fail in the process.      

The world-building in this show hardly makes sense: We are in middle-ages Japan, where people live behind big walls to guard themselves against humanoid monsters. Of course, the threat of the kabane would lead humans to develop techniques and technology that works against that threat, but please explain how being attacked by the kabane leads to  building railways all across Japan.  To begin with, Japan is not known for having a lot of easily accessible ore, so how did the people gather it and forg the metal for the walls, railways and trains?   It seems that the storywriters just tossed in whatever would be convenient for them so they could get the "from a to b plot" that is so typical for zombie-movies/series, totally ignoring the fact that the threat by the kabane would have had different effects than what is portrayed in the anime.

A lot of melodramatic flash-backs are inserted to make the viewers care about what is happening to the characters, but in all honesty, that is a cheap trick, much like killing off side-characters with little to no personality and screen-time just for shock-value. 

Another problem with this show is that the main antagonis is introduced way past the halfway point. This gives little chance for proper character-development of all the antagonizing characters


ART 8

The art of Koutetsujou no Kabaneri was nice to look at. Steampunk is almost always nice to look at, after all. The character designs have a vibe that is similar to mature anime from the early 2000's which is a nice change of pace since the VN style has taken the lead in modern anime The colors are vibrant most of the time and the surfaces often have a paint-ish look, much like in Seraph of the End, which was also produced by Studio Wit.


SOUND 5

There were a few instrumental versions and reinterpretations of the ending-song, but other than those, no particular OST stood out amongst them. Again, this remixing of Soundtracks in order to create a wider array of OST's is something that also happened with AoT, but at least that show had epic soundtracks, such as E.M.A and The Reluctant Heroes, that are immediately recognisable from the first beat onwards.


CHARACTER 3

Other than Ikoma and Mumei, the only character whose Personality is fleshed out to some extent is the main-antagonist, whom I shall not mention anymore to avoid major spoilers.

Both maincharacters have similar circumsrtances: They lost their family to the kabane when they were kids, and had to kill them to prevent their transformation into monsters. So, rather than coming to identify themselves with the human qualities of the characters, viewers were supposed to care about the characters becaus of shock-value. A lazy way out for the creators


Ikoma is the I-want-to-protect-everyone kind of MC who does not have any other significant features other than his motivation and his tragic past

Mumei is the same as Ikoma, but with an extra dish of snobby attitude and spreading her legs for onii-sama ( in a figurative sense )


The othr companions are hardly fleshed out, personality-wise. Takumi can simply be described as the useless best friend of the MC. There's nothing more to him than that.

The same thing goes for the female side-characters: Ayame acts like a typical well-raised Japanese Ojou-sama, the red-head is the standard stilent type, and the other girl is the caretaker character. Kind of like an onee-sama.


The antagonsists are equally on-dimensional. All of the less important antagonists follow the Main Antagonist for unclear reaons, much like in Guilty Crown, while the MA does have reasons for his what he does, even though the actions he takes are way too crass, considering his motives. 


ENJOYMENT 5 

As it is a typical zombie-flick, the show has a certain amount of tension and nice action scenes. No doubt, but for me, the incoherent developments throughout the story and the bland characters killed most the show fpr me. I'm just glad I don't get myself all too hyped up for shows without having seen source material, otherwise this show might have made me hate anime, considering the hype this show got from some parts of the community.


Overall a 5/10

Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress is an amazing anime to watch. Yes it doesn't have a lot of originality to it, but who cares as long as it's awesome. This anime, unlike a few other anime originals, knows not to tell a complicated plot. It keeps things relatively simple so people can be more easily invested. The Kabane are actually somewhat interesting, as it shows throughout the series that experienced Kabane can actually learn to a point.
I extremely enjoyed the cast, as likable characters. True some don't start out that great, but get better as the series progresses. The story can seem like it's tryingtoo hard to be dark sometimes though. The show was tense and kept me at the edge of my seat for a good part of the time.\n\n
There is also a realistic paranoia to the citizens. As people would be a bit paranoid in cases like these. I honestly don't understand the hate, yeah it has a lot of comparisons to attack on Titan, but in this day and Age originality is extremely difficult to find. So I prefer not to think about it. Also the soundtrack is amazing, and though the last episode didn't quite live up to expectations. I fully enjoyed and recommend this anime to any everywhere, though it's not for the faint of heart let me tell you

This anime gave me high hopes and then butchered those hopes while laughing maniacally. Many people complain that this is a Shingeki no Kyojin clone. I do not dispute that. However, in my view, this factor is not necessarily negative. When I entered this anime, I hoped for great art, and even greater action. At first, there was promise. But as I watched more and more, their initial potential disappeared faster than France during World War II. 
Koutetsujou no Kabaneri decided that within 12 episodes, they will be able to fully develop characters, and plot at the same time. The result is a steaming dumpof utter garbage on both ends. 


Characters are barely given any reasoning for their motive. For those that are given reasoning for their actions, the backstory is flimsy at best, and completely stupid at worst. Not only do the backstories not generate sympathy, they somehow managed to make me despise all of the characters. Somehow, they also managed to screw up unimportant characters. Characters with no backstories, ones who don't even matter, ones who we shouldn't even necessarily care too much about. This anime managed to make these characters act so irrationally, Scientologists would be shocked. As a result, my disgust is equally distributed among both the main characters and the filler characters.


 On the other hand, Koutetsujou no Kabaneri also managed to make their plot an utter clusterfuck. Not only does the plot move forward due to some of the crappiest motives possible, the plot itself is fraught with plot holes. Kabaneri manages to ignore its very rules, and discard their previous statements in order to continue their story. Not much can be said about the plot, but just understand that an eight year old can probably come up with a more elaborate, or exciting plot than the one which was written. 


Art and music are probably the only saving graces of the anime. However, it should be noted that the anime has a habit of taking still frames and shaking it in order to imply excitement or something. I don't know. 


Ok, now there will be spoilers ahead. Its kind of a personal rant, but also a review on why everything is as stupid as it is, with specific examples. 


Lets begin with episode one. In episode one we are introduced to Ikoma, the MC. He also happens to have a permanent scowl, be angry at everyone and everything, and also seems to believe that other people are assholes. He is not wrong on that at least. The people in this world are assholes, but more on that later. So Ikoma is hell bent on creating this badass new weapon which will allow him to destroy these uber zombies, that have super strong heart cages. These cages, it seems, can not be destroyed with normal means, which is why he needs extremely high penetration power. Remember this statement, its important later. Anyhow, his good friend, Takumi gives him an idea on fixing up his gun by adding more gunpowder. More gunpowder=bigger explosion. Who could have fucking guessed. So on this day, a train suddenly appears, after some delay. People are concerned, but for some reason, decide to open the gates. Ok. Lets talk about this. They are in a post apocalyptic world. Super zombies roam everywhere. Does it not occur to them to confirm the train is working and not zombie filled before letting it in? How were the train tracks built anyway? But lets just say they were hungover or something, and just opened the gates. The zombies come in, fuck things up. Ikoma remembers he has his super gun, and goes to get it. He shoots a zombie and it works. Yay. But he's bitten. Oh no. But then he remembers its a fucking virus which infects him, and he decides that he needs to prevent it from reaching his brain, so he starts choking himself. He does not realize that choking himself slows down the blood but does not stop it, but because of plot armor, the virus realizes its dealing with a badass, and shouldn't touch this dude, so it stops, turning him into a fake zombie. Once again. This dude just figured out how to stop the virus. It might be vital information and all, but maybe it just slipped from his mind during the attack. Ya know. One of the ways to save humanity. Moving on. We are also introduced to Mumei, a badass fighting half-loli. Kabane are meant to be scary ass motherfuckers that humanity doesnt know how to deal with, which is why they are stuck behind walls. Yet Mumei manages to mow down a ton using bladed shoes(apparently cutting off their head works now, whereas we were told that it needed to be heart cage), and shooting their heart cages with regular pistols. Seriously, what the fuck. Remember being told that regular guns don't work? Lol they work now, jk about that. Ikoma is a loser after all. She also manages to shove sharp stuff into their heart cages. To do so should be near impossible if most guns require multiple shots, but hey, plot armor amiright? I do have to say, Mumei remurdering zombies was interesting. If they just had her do that all anime, it would have been watchable without extreme pain coursing through me. Anyway, they get on a train to run away, but people become scared of Ikoma and Mumei, because they are kabaneri. They decide to go full retard, because having effective zombie killing machines as body guards isnt nice, and its better to just kill them off. Confining them makes sense perhaps, to ensure they're not bloodthirsty(which they are, but in a literal sense), but straight out getting rid of your only weapons? A pretty bad idea. Within the next few episodes, they decide to expand upon character. Mumei it turns out, had her parents killed when she was young, and then got turned into a person who believes the strong survive and the weak should die. She then goes through a mental breakdown, which nobody cares about, because all it does is take away from the action. Moreso, the flashback is so dry, and shown in such a disjointed way, that really, nobody cares by the time its finished. So soon, we meet our main antagonist, a dude named Justin Biba. He has pink hair, and he seems nice. However, he actually has a nefarious plan. His dad at one point left him to die after sending him to attack the kabane. Because of this one incident, Justin decides that he needs to destroy all of humanity, and all the innocent. His logic is so coherent he is able to convince creationists that evolution is true. So using this super logic. he manages to get a bunch of followers. His followers literally have no motive. Nothing went wrong to them(Biba's original band of men were all annihilated), they just decided that Justin Biba's pink hairstyle is too kool to not follow. So it should also be noted that kabane are able to become big black monsters. No specific explanation, we're just told that if you inject them with magic water, they somehow deny physics, and suck other kabane towards them. On the other hand, kabaneri are also able to use kamehamehas and emit energy from their body. No explanation here either, except plot told you so. If the anime bothered to allocate a tiny bit of their resources to explaining the abilities, perhaps it would not be an utter failure. We also find out that Justin Biba had the cure to being kabane. Just let it be ya know, the cure and nobody but Biba's people are able to find it. Oh. And Justin, after trying to kill Ikoma, decides that it is in his best interest to cure him. Lol no reason why. Jesus. 


Yea, I am so done with this anime. Many might ask why I watched all 12 episodes. It was out of morbid curiosity. I regret every single second now. I had more fun writing this review than watching the anime. And this review is damn boring. So cheers.

The first thing that came into my mind when I saw the PV of this anime was the film "SnowPiercer" which has got a similar premise.(Only traveling in the train part).
Let start with the review
Story 6/10
Well if you have watched Attack on Titan then its pretty much the same. The only difference here is the creatures are called kabane and if they bite you. You turn into one too. 
Art and Animation 10/10
The art and the animation is just beautiful. its a visual treat. The fight scenes look amazing. You can expect Attack on titan season 2 to have the same quality.
Music 8/10
This first thingi did when i found out about this series was check who the music composer was, it is none other than Hiroyuki Sawano of whom i am a big fan of. The man behind the OST of AOT,Guilty Crown, Mobile suit gundam Unicorn.


The music is damn amazing. Mixing orchestral elements with rock and electronic elements. Typical sawano style. Some of my favourite tracks are "Through My Blood" , "88城" , "克JOU気MACHINE甲" ,"Vivalabiba". "KGK" reminds me of XL-TT from AOT.


Sound 10/10

Voice acting is perfect. No complains.



Character 7/10 

once again a lot of similarities to AOT. Ikoma Is similar to Eren but more than killing all of the kabane his aim is to save everyone. 

Mumei, being the female lead is one of my favourite characters of the show. she cool, badass. Her backstory is also quite similar to that of Mikasa's.


Enjoyment 7/10

personally It isn't as good as AOT but there are some epic moments which are awesome. It serves as a good supplement for AOT fans.

 after you finish watching the series your left with mixed feelings like something was missing. It had great potential to become one of best anime this season but i feel that 12 episodes just wasn't enough to tell the entire story. either it should have been 24 episodes or they should make a second season because there are a lot of unanswered questions. Anyhow it's an ok series, If you enjoyed AOT , you'll enjoy this. But watch it without any expectations, because if you do. You'll be disappointed.

Why was the Lexus SC430 voted as the worst car of all time by Top Gear? Sure, there are worse cars, but in most cases, you got what you expected. Kabaneri is the same as that stupid Lexus - it gave us so many high hopes - the setting, the art style and animation quality, all the potential for an interesting world, characters and development. But instead of telling us anything about the world, giving us some kind of solid story or likeable characters, we were presented with no real content. They didn't even need to build a strong history, Attack on Titan is prettymuch "100 years ago, things went bad and we built walls, nobody knows what exactly happened". But they didn't bother doing even this much. No info, how, when or why the kabane appeared, how the people are actually living in the world, if this is a national plague or has the whole world gone to hell?


The characters were written by a 14-year old. They are paper cut-outs of archetypal cliches. It's just teenage angst piled on more teenage angst.


If this had been produced on a limited animation budget and couldn't ride the Attack on Titan hype train, it would have been instantly regarded as a generic 5/10 zombie flick with angsty teenagers. I would have dropped it after the 2nd episode and would have had no regrets. But it managed to keep my hopes up for a whole season, thus actually being the greatest disappointment for me in the last 5 years.

*Spoilers below, though I have not given away the villain's identity or the ending*
The supernatural has captivated our imagination for generations. For all the horror that usually abounds these tropes, many storytellers use supernatural elements to comment on human nature. In the many titles focusing on zombie apocalypses, this is especially true. Rick and his merry band fight humanity at its worst throughout much of The Walking Dead. Joel and Ellie battle hunters and cannibals as they try to find the cure for the fungal zombie virus in The Last of Us. It fascinates us and horrifies us when we see what humanity is capableof to survive in a world that turns against them. Kabaneri tries to comment on the human condition, it really really tries. It’s too bad that it doesn’t get to that point until halfway through the season. 


Story: For at least ten years, humanity has been plagued by the unrelenting appetite of the Kabane, Kabaneri’s version of zombies. Kabane are portrayed as strong, mindless undead humans who can only be killed by piercing their glowing heart, a feat near impossible by normal methods. Most humans have found shelter in walled cities connected by railroads, though many of these “stations” have fallen to the Kabane over the years. The mysterious Prince Biba roams the countryside in his armed train killing many Kabane and the country’s elite find protection in the capital. Kabaneri begins at a peaceful station that is quickly overrun when a train carrying a hoard of Kabane breaches the gates. Ikoma, our green haired protagonist, is bitten in the ensuing chaos, but is able to stave off the infection by choking himself. The survivors flee in a train named the Koutetsujou, with Ikoma and Mumei allowed on with huge trepidation.  


And thus the title of the show is explained. Ikoma and Mumei are both Kabaneri, or people who have been bitten by Kabane but whose brains are still human. Kabaneri are inhumanly strong, but with that strength comes a price: they need blood to survive. The first few episodes are sprinkled with prejudice and distrust towards both Kabaneri despite their repeated help. This whole plot point quickly becomes tired and boring, with people welcoming Mumei one minute and decrying her the next. Ikoma is kept locked away for the most part, but many fear him. They are not fully accepted by the people until they save everyone again in episode four, and by then it’s been at least three solid episodes of distrust, prejudice. and even a coup on the train. 


The writers for this series take many liberties in the face of advancing the plot, usually coming up with idiotic ways for humanity to fuck itself over. In episode one, for instance, the guards for the gate into the city decide to lower the drawbridge for a fast moving, oncoming train (later revealed to have many Kabane on board) instead of waiting for the train to come to a complete stop. This of course jumpstarts the plot, but it puts into question how humanity has survived for so long when the guardians of the city can’t even perform basic checks on a train before letting it into the city proper. 


In spite of all this, as a survival story Kabaneri was fairly enjoyable. The battle against the black shadow was a marvel to look at visually and the music only added to the fight. But the shows’ hubris catches up with it and inexplicably the story tries to focus on the human condition instead. It is a badly done critique though, because the main villain is one dimensional and ridiculous and the whole thing spirals into a terribly done revenge plot instead. The villain's motivations are thin at best and the loyalty of his soldiers is laughable. The story tries to pin the emergence of the Kabane on the elites in the capital but even this is barely explored. The direction the plot decides to go is completely terrible. Remember what I said earlier about how the writers come up with bullshit reasons to advance the plot? It’s not a good critique on humanity when a crazy person is the one bringing all of the misery in the last few episodes. Tearing apart the rest of Kabaneri’s flimsy story means tearing apart the characters, so on we go. 


Characters: I’ll be blunt: I don’t like Mumei. Or Ikoma really. But Mumei’s character really irks me. She’s incredibly naïve and idiotic at the best of times. Her personality is constantly shifting: one minute she’s cute and smiley and the next she’s intense and frowning. She says or does something that doesn’t sit right with the people around her and doesn’t offer a logical explanation. She doesn’t listen to what the leader of the group tells her to do when they are on missions. She’s constantly thinking about how only the strong can survive, weak people should die, etc. etc. It’s amazing that these people actually like her. She doesn’t think badly of the villain ever, and even when he betrays her trust she still goes back to him. She knows he lied to her but she goes back. She trusts him to not do anything to her when she just witnessed a friend get fucked over by him. Yes, she’s only a girl, but it’s insane that she still trusts him after she saw him do. The rest of her plot is predictable, boring, and contrived. The villain proves that her badass characterization is moot, manipulates her, and eventually turns her against her friends. The fact that she’s responsible for the deaths of thousands of people doesn’t help my opinion of her. 


Ikoma is also frustrating at times, but not on the level of Mumei. He is the typical shounen protagonist: young, naïve, and mostly weak. His contribution to this world is a steel piecing projectile weapon. Most of the time he’s tagging after Mumei trying to make her a decent human being, which is almost impossible. His naivety is frustrating and as a character he really doesn’t add much to the story. He isn’t really necessary. He is only Mumei’s link to humanity and since I don’t care for Mumei at all, I really can’t care about Ikoma either. In the last few episodes her gets an appearance change (arguably to indicate that he is a badass now) and his character arc seemed to be going a a good direction. It's too bad the writers didn't have the balls to follow through with it. 


And then there’s The Villain. Until episode 7, the only thing the audience knows about him is that he is Mumei’s “older brother” and that he is the one that has told her that only the strong should survive. This person is our antagonist and until episode 7 we have not seen him ever. This is terrible writing. At this point in the story I was convinced that the Kabane would continue to be the antagonists because who else could it possibly be? That guy Mumei talks about occasionally? No goddamn way. How could I get invested in an antagonist’s motives with only five episodes left of the series? How could I possibly care about this dude? Right from the beginning when he was introduced I knew he was an asshole. He kills people with a smile on his face. He’s cruel, manipulative, and callous. He treats his servants like expendable objects. He throws away a kabaneri like it’s nothing. He lies to Mumei and destroys an entire station, killing thousands, just to send a message to his father. And why? Why is he doing this? Because his father was mean to him when he was younger. Because his father didn’t care about him enough to try to save him. And so now, he has to go around and kill thousands of people just because he has daddy issues. It’s a ridiculous, tired motivation and the fact that this is the antagonist a zombie anime is going with is ridiculous. This guy manipulated a young impressionable girl who had just lost her mother and turned her into a kabaneri because he was angry with his dad. The fact that he has people that are still loyal to him is baffling. He’s throwing a humongous temper tantrum, but it’s not cute because he’s killing everyone instead of yelling at them.


Animation and Sound: The animation is great. The composer is the same one that did Attack on Titan, so the soundtrack is wonderful. I could say that it sounds a little too much like AoT, but composers have their own style, so I can’t fault him for that. The voice acting is good for the most part. Yuki Kaji is distinctive as he always is for me, but it’s not distracting. Tasuku Hatanaka’s voice work for Ikoma is painful to listen to. He did good work on Ushio to Tora, but because his voice is so distinctive it felt like I was listening to Ushio talk about zombies for the entire show. It didn’t help that the second season of Ushio was airing at the same time. 


Kabaneri looked like a promising anime at the beginning, with a decent survival plot unfurling nicely. However, the story suddenly does a huge 180 into a story that has no relevance to the one previously set up. In the end, all that’s left are the shambles of a promising story and a garbage pile of shitty characterization, contrived plot points, and terrible writing. It was good as a survival story, but it’s terrible as a revenge story. I’ll just play The Last of Us again next time.

I'll keep my review short, because I don't want to waste any more time than necessary on this anime.
Story: 3
Art: 9
Sound: 9
Character: 3
Enjoyment: 5
Overall: 6
In short, it had a great soundtrack and amazing artwork, but those were the only things I liked. It was eye-candy or fan-service with no substance. (Don't get me wrong — there is no actual "fan-service")
It started off really well with a cool (yet generic) idea, brilliant art and music, great suspense and excitement-building, and decent character concepts, but then it just went downhill from there. When it really got bad was when the show's main antagonist arrived. Basically, as soonas they tried to introduce a real plot, things went south. Also, the characters gradually became less and less likeable the more you got to know them.\n\n
It looks like they're setting things up for a second season, but I, personally, do not want one. That's not something I say very often...

Koutetsujou no kabaneri or kabaneri of the iron fortress was honestly a thrill ride from beginning to end. From the first episode to the last its almost nonstop action. 
When it comes to opening themes they're supposed to be songs that kind of give a hint as to the overall feel of the show, and man, Egoist did a great job at that. overall the music did a good job at accenting certain parts of the show.
Character development however, could have been better, it was alright, but they still kinda seemed, a little shallow, which is fine if your not nit picky. (As i saidthe action does a great job at carrying the show.)\n\n
Story and pacing were excellent, never did it feel like the show was moving to fast for it own good. Set in the industrial age where everybody relied on steam products, (including weapons.) added to overall action.\n\n
Overall koutetsujou no kabaneri was an amazing thrill ride that leaves you wanting more after each episode, if you enjoyed shingeki no kyojin, (attack on titan.) you would most definitely enjoy this one aswell.

Just to be clear, this will be more of a comment on the anime than a review. This anime had so much potential and just... didn't turn out to be much. The first few episodes were incredibly enjoyable. There's so much backstory that they never touched on. So much they didn't put in between each episode and very low amount of character development...
12 episodes just wasn't enough for this anime... It's a shame an anime with such potential was cut down to virtually nothing. I can only rate this a 5 as a mediocre anime because of that. I wanted to like this anime butit just was poorly made.\n\n
Rating: 5/5

Every so often, there would be a certain hype train that blows out of the tunnels yelling out “Anime of The Year” before it have even has a little chance of promoting itself. Let alone actually premiering a single episode. For that is how the anime community has become. But what are the chances of finding an anime of such a grand scale and setting such as this with high production value? Though of course as we are a demanding bunch we're just sitting at our computers still scratching our heads wondering "Where's SnK Season 2?".
That being said. How does Kabaneri of The Iron Fortressreally hold up to the hype of what was meant to be Attack on Titan Season 2 or it a steamed roll of disappointment?  


Plot: 7/10


As it stands, the story of a steampunk, samurai age zombie dramatic thriller story was a nice sparkle of something refreshing from your typical harems or action anime that’s shown seasonally. It's not often you find a decent zombie anime of sorts in current times. Though of course being the studio that animated Attack on Titan, it borrows a few tropes from the series and makes it their own here. Settings and character wise. Unfortunately despite the high value to presentation doesn’t stop the show being filled with the old plot hole and plot device convenience. The show is just riddled with them it somewhat ruins the atmosphere and feel like the show is just stuck on rails to become what it is. How did humanity make railways and walls overtime with kabaneri roaming everywhere? Where did the kabaneri even come from?  


Was the plot entertaining? By all means it sure was, if not being generic at some points. The little plot twists we’re few but enough to keep me intrigued. Sweet animated fight scenarios and heavy amounts of drama between characters kept the atmosphere peaked within scenes.


Though the characters back stories still have left much to mystery and assumptions as they we're minor scenes that left even more plot holes than I'd like.


Art/Animation: 9/10


Definitely getting high marks was if not is the biggest highlight to the entire anime series. Animation was top notch as it was switching between 3D and 2D animation with such streamlined quality. As you can expect of course after working on Season 1 of SnK. However as an original series with no source content, the world is beautiful, vivid and rich with so much detail it leaves you times of shock and awe. It had the quality of an hour long movie yet stretched across 12 episodes of epicness. Of course there are more eye boggling works out there, but I’m a simple man.


Sound: 10/10


As a big fan of Egoist it isn’t a surprise that I was largely impressed with the fantastic opening that it had. As well as having Aimer for the ED, I couldn’t have been happier with their choices of artists here. The soundtrack and BGM we’re composed by the one and only Hiroyuki Sawano, whom composed the background music for highly renowned anime such as  Guilty Crown and Attack On Titan. It was amazing to watch the battle scenes with such intense music. Sound effects for the steam guns, trains, zombies and etc. we’re great. The voicing of the characters was on point as well. No one felt out of place for neither their characters nor their designs.


Characters: 8/10


Now this is where things seem very similar to Attack on Titan in like every way possible. Not to say that’s a bad thing of course. We have The Main duo protagonists Ikoma and Mumei. Ikoma being your typical shounen character ripped straight out of a manga. His got the willpower, confidence and a leader like feel about him. He is also a very noble to the cause guy who wouldn’t give a rat’s ass of getting bit for his comrade’s sake. However what he does lack is any character development. Sure he may be a keen bad-ass guy from episode 1. But after completing the series I feel like he hasn’t changed much whatsoever. For better or worse I’m not completely sure. But he felt kind of disappointing Mumei on the other hand (#Best-girl) is a mix bag of cuteness and bad-ass wrapped up into a package. She’s a lovely girl who’s been through hell and back to achieve her goals. Some could say she’s naive and childish with some of her choices throughout the series and I can agree as it gave me times of questioning it myself. That being said she’s only like 15 or 16 (assumingly). So her decisions do reflect her age and I respect that they decided to follow that rather than being a generic female main.  


Side characters we’re a solid addition to the cast other than the “let’s kick these guys off the train” people of course. But it wouldn’t be a zombie apocalypse setting if there wasn’t these people aren’t scared to do what they think is right themselves despite the circumstances. As such a large majority of the supporting cast is as such. However to find  these characters as controversial is one thing, but to first emphasise with their choices and see why is a whole other thing which I wish more people take into consideration before judging the characters indiscriminately. Moving on the other main supports we’re a necessary bunch to keep the series bumped up with their own personalities and traits to have the characters feel more varied.


The antagonists of the story we’re probably as evil as they come. Fuelled by the desires of revenge and survival of the fittest ideals, they really brought the anime plot more alive. I really liked the antagonist this time around. Oddly enough he had an aura of being beyond human nature that enticed me to continuously be curious to what he may plot next. It’s a rare response I ever have for any antagonist, so here’s to say he was a pretty good one. 


Enjoyment/Overall: 7/10


Despite the many plot holes and small flaws I could further list, I thoroughly enjoyed the series as a whole. And I do admit that I too was on the hype train starting from the first PV. It was a great series that I would recommend to people looking for the steampunk, zombie or action genre. Though it isn’t Attack on Titan Season 2 it’s still something to watch while we wait for its release sometime later this year.

Ok, this is the first time I'm writing a review given that I judge anime based on enjoyment for the most part, there are exeptions but those will be in my profile soon... maybe. I'd probably get down to it eventualy (talking about my rating system)
But anyway, I bet you're wondering why I even bothered making a review given that I judge a series based on my personal enjoyment of the series for the most part
It's because this series had my hopes up. It had the best art style since the fate series, I liked it's themes and the main characters were not cookie cutter"where's my momma, I'm so scared" type of characters.... For the first 4 episodes


The first four episodes of this series were just absolutely brilliant. The dynamic between Ikoma and Mumei was also great


The background music was fantastic and fit every scene perfectly and the credits were absolutely amazing, specially the ending song Ninelie


But.... everything changed after the fire natio- nevermind, everything changed after the first 4 episodes. Thinking back, they could've just ended it after the first four episodes, it did feel like an ending and a lot of people said so when episode 4 came out. I was one of the people who were first to say that there are a lot more left to be explored, this great show has to continue. Little did I know that the continuation of this series is going to be well, shit


It started going off track, ironically. Choosing that track resulted into the once great train that was able to protect the people inside it and make them feel safe be reduced to nothing but a trainwreck which will most likely be used by homeless people as their shelter from the rain. Only a shadow of what it once was


Overall, this series starts off really strong but then went downhill from there until they reached a point where the tracks were cut off and a cliff was right ahead, this series tried to step on the brakes as hard as it could trying to save itself but it still crashed and fell into oblivion. They had all the time in the world to realize that there's a cliff ahead but the people on this train's control room were too busy looking back on what the train has done so far and the places it has taken them to notice thus leading to their own demise

This is my first review and it will be very short.
Had the anime followed the quality of its 1st half, I would have given it a 8/10 easily, maybe a bit more. The art is nice, the OST pretty good with some very nice tracks here and there and world design quite interesting with its own take on zombies and survival in a steampunkish feudal Japan
Instead it took a plunge at the 2nd half introducing character designs not fitting the setting and pretty crappy events with dull motivations. 
The end of episode 11 hinted towards some resolutions and heavy action / drama. Instead we getthrown some pretty crappy action and a barely interesting end.

Alright kabaneri of the iron fortress's first season is finally finished and so we can have a more balanced and complete impression on the anime.It started in a great way showing hints of a great anime in progress,which actually explains all the hype around the show.
The first 4 episodes or so were really interesting and pretty enjoyable keeping the viewers intrigued and wanting more.However, after that a huge downfall began in almost every aspect of the anime.From what we had seen in the first episodes it didn't seem like this show actually cares about character development that much but it seemed to be concentrating onthe action part.However that isn't an excuse of the worst character development that i 've seen in any anime.I do not want to spoil anything so I m just gonna say that at some point of the anime the whole situation gets unrealistic and rather ridiculous(i am refering to ikoma's resolve,suddenly becoming more strong and  mature without anything triggering him).\n
What I also noticed is that there were some plot holes.Maybe that was because they didn't want to reveal any further information  for some reason,but it rather made the story a bit complex and at some points,allow me to say,ridiculous.It is too bad that an anime with great such potential and support,even though it was a mix of copied ideas from series,movies and other animes,commited suicide.The fact that it changes its whole course from surving against the kabane to defeating the human enemies,while lowering the threat of the kabane at a overwhelmimg rate seems just a child's mistake.It is like the threat,the danger and the way to deal with kabane was no problem for anyone when the conflict between humans began.Don't get me wrong I understand the creator's intention not to mess things up a lot and confuse and exhaust the audience,but it seems more like everything was being rushed.Perhaps it would be better if it consisted of more episodes and it was slow paced.\n
Anyway in the end it is not a bad anime,but a rather acceptable one.The impressive action scenes and the animation was great which make up for the rest.So in case you wanna see a anime with plenty of action and blood spilling and you don't care about the story at all then it is a pretty good recommendation from me.

Starting with what I DO like: I like the concept, and I like the art.
that's really it. The big problem is the characters. The male lead starts off sort of interesting, but he never seems to actually do much of anything. The female lead is the typical emotionless edgy teen and every time she's on the screen she's just annoying.
The side characters are mostly uninteresting as well.
I just could not get invested in the story because I couldn't bring myself to give a shit about anybody. I really wanted to like it because the concept is good, but every episode I watched just ended withdisappointment.\n\n
Also, the music is really bad and unfitting.

Kabaneri has a reputation as an AOT clone which is very justified given the plot,director,composer and studio. While some people say Kabaneri is better than AOT they are an extremely small minority while most proclaim it as a version that does basically everything wrong. I'm in a relatively grey area. I do think Kabaneri is worse than AOT but I think it does SOME things better. Let's talk about what it does wrong.Firstly is the horror aspect of the show or even if you wouldn't call it that the tension or sense of dread that is needed for any action drama.AOT despite its flaws isgreat at creating tension at least in the first season. Firstly is the setting. The idea of being enclosed in a wall surrounded by giants driven by the sole motive of murdering you with no way out immediately strikes you with a sense of claustrophobia and oppression,an idea explored frequently in the show itself.Kabaneri has a world where multiple stations exist removing much of the crushing feeling of being trapped. Also the show kind of treats a station being destroyed as no-biggy while AOT always treats even a breach as groundbreaking development with devastating effects.There also aren't any unpredictable chaos factors like the Armoured or Colossal Titan and most of the breaches either happen because humanity is completely retarded or (spoilers from this point on) someone wants it to. The Kabane also just aren't as effective monsters as the Titans lacking the uncanny valley effect the Titans have,nor the ginormous retard strength the Titans always display and also lacking a commanding presence.The Kabaneri this show's version of Titan shifters have about three main problems.One is that the method their created begs the question of why everyone doesn't become one.Two is they are much much stonger than the Kabane with the Kabane only posing a threat when they make stupid decisions or when they're that weird fused colony thing. Three is that they're powers get really out there as the show progresses with the aforementioned colonies,a goddamn laser beam and even better superhuman strength with very few established limitations.Then is the whole Kabaneri are evil conflict that goes on for far too long instead of like how it went for one scene in AOT.

Now what does it do better than AOT. Well I liked the characters more. They certainly have more I can say about them unlike that one Marco dude.However,unlike the AOT characters(at least the suppporting characters) who will probably develop down the line I can't see that happening for the characters of this show. It all feels more processed and like they're just there to fill roles. I like Ikoma and Mumei for the first seven episodes. Ikoma unlike Eren who pretty much just screams is a lot more settled and optimistic which is refreshing to say the least. Mumei starts of as bootleg Mikasa but I like how the power dynamic between the mains begins to tilt and they aren't afraid to show her as vulnerable.

However, some pink haired twink comes along and ruins everything. Mumei becomes a damsel in distress in one of the most trite ways possible, Ikoma loses his likability and his motives are muddier than the river I find 4 slippers in every day.And that final episode is one of the biggest clusterfucks(pardon my language) I've ever seen.


About the production I can't say much most don't already know. The show looks gorgeous with a semi retro aesthetic and beautiful character and world design and that Sawano soundtrack is just MMMMMMMMHHH.


Although I like Kabaneri it has a lot of wasted potential and while I like it I'm afraid I can only give it a 5/10.Its a fun action romp that becomes less fun after episode 8. Make sure you keep your brain turned off all the way though

kinda feels like the creator didnt really know what genre to center the show around. it feels like a miss mash of western movies. combining "i am legend"and "snowpiercer" but its set in a feudal japanese environment post opening borders to america and england. 
the characters are bland and 2 dimensional however its interesting to see a main character embrace his affliction instead of crumpling into despair (e.g tokyo ghoul). 
im not going to talk about the main villain because he is so void of any backstory, progressive narrative and clear motive that he basically didnt exist past the times he was on screen
as theviewer there is no attachment to the world i couldn't care less if a town is destroyed or someone loses a family\n\n
besides the curse afflicted people there is nothing special about the art \n\n
its really not worth your time unless youve always thought " ya know what would have made i am legend better? if they spent 50% of the time in a train"

I'm not a fan of writing long essays unless its a school requirement so I'll keep it brief
Story: 7/10
It was a 9/10 when they were still in the train. When they left the train it stopped becoming what it was.

The first few episodes looked like it got the budget for a ufotable film but waned at the last episode. EH

I felt the hate. I felt the annoyance. I felt like punching that dickhead through the screen.
