More likely than not, you have without a doubt heard of the anime series Attack On Titan.  The idea of giant humanoid looking giants eating people for no reason other than impulse sounds both terrifying and exciting at the same time.  Well imagine the entire idea of attack on titan but with zombies.  Kabaneri Of The Iron Fortress is about the human race on the verge of extinction due to the zombie like creatures known as Kabane.  The only way to kill these dreadful monsters is to literally pierce their iron heart.  
Story wise, at first, I found it tobe a nice idea and a great concept.  As I watched more of the series I realized that so many details and aspects seemed like a direct rip off of the Attack On Titan anime.  Everything from the main characters drive and desire to eliminate the kabane, down to the way people have protected themselves from the outside world for so many years due to the outrageous number of zombie like creatures that inhabit the land outside.  I'm not saying in anyway that the story was bad.  I just think that their could have been a little bit more originality behind it.  


Remember how I said that a lot of things in this anime seem directly related to Shingeki no Kyojin?  Well even the characters share direct similarities.  Most likely when you think of the phrase "fight fire with fire" you have an idea of what has to be done to eliminate an an enemy threat by either asking the enemy for help or literally becoming one with those that you hate.  That's exactly what happens in Attack On Titan and this show.  Even the secondary character share similarities with Mikasa.       


Aside from its flaws, Kabaneri of The Iron Fortress did a good job with making me wait with anticipation with what will happen next.  Everything seems almost impossible to accomplish in the world of the Kabane, but their was always a gleam of hope when you take the time to look for it.  It was definitely suspenseful and mysterious.  Two things I absolutely love.  I felt relatively satisfied after my run through with the anime.


If you want a short anime that will make you feel dread wonder what events occurred to make the primary and secondary characters take the paths that they chose, then take the time out watch the Kabane fight what is known as the Kabaneri and see how what little faith they have is restored.

- English Review (Translated version)
I'll be honest, my first impression with "Koutetsujou no Kabaneri" was very, very poor. And when I say first impression I'm not talking about the first few minutes, not even the first chapter, I'm talking about practically half of the series. Yes, until about 6th, the series is a clash of clichés (more than usual) and a style... "based" on others animes like "Shingeki no Kyojin".
About this idea, it is coherent that when sharing production and study (Wit Studio) you see certain similarities between both anime. It's logical, do you think? But that's a bit too much for me to swallow...what we can see here is not "inspiration", it is not "a tribute", this is something that surpasses those fine lines to become a fucking plagiarism: argument (mankind cornered before a threat in the form of creatures), protagonist (half between the human race and those creatures, and he is used as a key weapon), musical style (abuse of epic music and choral melodies)... so written does not seem to be so much, but believe me, it is so excessive.


Anyway, when I talk about that the first part of "Koutetsujou no Kabaneri" is quite improveable, I do not say it just because they act like a Ditto with another anime. The main fault I saw is the insistence on an epic that does not exist. In an exaggerated number of scenes, simple as they are, put the epics songs and melodies and try to force memorable scenes when it is neither necessary nor can be achieved that way. Of course, after seeing these attempts over and over again, after each chapter has (or they want to have) at least two-three scenes like that, what is produced is the opposite effect, no one believes them.


Then there are certain argumentative inconsistencies, although they are minor failures. For example, mankind have spent years fighting with the Kabane with weapons that do not conform to them, but the protagonist without being disheartened is able to devise a firearm, a weapon and a way to avoid transformation. Or that it is so complicated to kill them (theoretically the only way is to pierce the heart with much power) and suddenly you see kabane dying because they cut off their heads.


But then comes episode 7 (very quiet, "filler" for the tiresome) and from there the series is completely transformed as to how you develop and present the story. The epic is finished with shoehorn in each scene, the stigma of brazen plagiarism is finished. It is at this moment that "Koutetsujou no Kabaneri" detaches itself from that elongated shadow and begins to offer us things by itself.


Nor is it any wonder, do not misunderstand me, but at least it's much better than those first few episodes because you skip many of your failures until then. It is true that the story is somewhat run over and confused, not given much data and this makes the end is also somewhat precipitated in my point of view. Although it is something expected when only consists of 12 episodes and half of them are mediocre to the extreme.


Finally I wanted to mention the soundtrack, which is very good. The melodies on stage (no matter how often their use is forced) have a tremendous charisma. The opening is not bad, it complies, but it lacks something. At all times it seems like it goes half-gas, it does not finish booting nor stands out at all. In contrast, the ending is of enormous quality and makes its role much better. This comes to be like a kind of analogy with the anime itself. It starts without a definite site, without being anything special, lacking spark, but ends up much better executed and leaving a good taste. That is "Koutetsujou no Kabaneri".



- Spanish Review (Original and faithful version)


Voy a ser sincero, mi primera impresión con "Koutetsujou no Kabaneri" fue muy, pero que muy deficiente. Y cuando digo primera impresión no estoy hablando de los primeros minutos, ni siquiera del primer capítulo, estoy hablando de prácticamente la mitad de la serie. Sí, hasta más o menos el capítulo 6 la serie es un batiburrillo de clichés (más de lo normal) y un estilo calcado a otros anime como "Shingeki no Kyojin".


En cuanto a esto último, me parece muy bien que al compartir producción y estudio (Wit Studio) se vean ciertas similitudes entre ambos anime. Es algo lógico, ¿no? Pero que nadie quiera hacerme comulgar con ruedas de molino... lo que podemos ver aquí no es "inspiración", no es "un homenaje", esto es algo que sobrepasa esas finas líneas para convertirse en un jodido plagio: argumento (humanidad acorralada ante una amenaza en forma de criaturas), protagonista (a medias entre la raza humana y esas criaturas, se le usa de arma clave), estilo musical (abuso de música épica y melodías corales)... así escrito igual no parece para tanto, pero creedme, lo es.


De todas formas, cuando hablo de que la primera parte de "Koutetsujou no Kabaneri" es bastante mejorable, no lo digo solamente porque se hayan marcado un Ditto con otro anime. El fallo principal que le veo es la insistencia en una épica que no existe. En un número exagerado de escenas, por simples que sean, por poca chicha que se les pueda sacar, meten las canciones y melodías de corte épico e intentan forzar unas escenas memorables cuando ni es necesario ni se puede conseguir de esa manera. Como es lógico, después de ver estos intentos una y otra vez, después de que en cada capítulo haya (o quieren que haya) mínimo dos-tres escenas así, lo que se produce es el efecto contrario, nadie se las cree.


Luego hay ciertas inconsistencias argumentales, aunque son fallos menores. Por ejemplo que la humanidad lleve años luchando con los kabane con armas no acordes a ellos, pero el protagonista sin despeinarse sea capaz de idear un arma de fuego, un arma blanca y una forma de evitar la transformación. O que sea tan complicado matarlos (teóricamente la única forma es atravesarles el corazón con mucha potencia) y de pronto te veas kabane muriendo porque les cortan la cabeza.


Pero entonces llega el capítulo 7 (muy tranquilo, "de relleno" para los pesados) y a partir de ahí la serie se transforma completamente en cuanto a su forma de desarrollar y presentar la historia. Se acaba la épica metida con calzador en cada escena, se acaba el sambenito de plagio descarado. Es en este momento en el que "Koutetsujou no Kabaneri" se desprende de esa sombra alargada y empieza a ofrecernos cosas por sí misma.


Tampoco ninguna maravilla, no me entendáis mal, pero al menos es mucho mejor que esos primeros capítulos porque pule muchos de sus fallos hasta entonces. Cierto es que la historia es algo atropellada y confusa, no se dan muchos datos y esto hace que el final sea también algo precipitado bajo mi punto de vista. Aunque es algo esperable cuando solo consta de 12 episodios y la mitad de ellos son mediocres hasta el extremo.


Por último quería hacer mención a la banda sonora, que es muy buena. Las melodías en escena (por mucho que en bastantes ocasiones su uso sea forzado) tienen un carisma tremendo. El opening no es malo, cumple, pero le falta algo. En todo momento parece que como que va a medio gas, que no termina de arrancar ni destaca en nada. En contraposición, el ending es de una calidad enorme y hace su papel mucho mejor. Esto viene a ser como una especie de analogía con el anime en sí. Empieza sin un sitio definido, sin ser nada especial, faltándole chispa, pero termina de forma mucho mejor ejecutada y dejando un buen sabor de boca. Eso es "Koutetsujou no Kabaneri".

IMPORTANT PSA: The first time that the main characters set out on the train, start playing the Thomas the Tank Engine theme. I am 100% serious, you will not regret this choice. The timing had us howling with laughter.
Oh, right, the anime. You guys remember Attack On Titan, right? Did you ever want to see that but with trains and zombies? Maybe?
Nah.
I don't even know where to start, this was such a.........
Mass of train cars derailed in a ditch forming a flaming pile of wreckage.
The show is utterly beautiful. Its soundtrack is amazing. It's a shame that the writing was worse than mine. Characters areshallow or pointless, motivations have the depth of a drying puddle, and really cool imagery is wasted at every opportunity. If this was just a portfolio filler, everyone involved should have gotten a pat on the back. The art and sound teams did their damnedest, and they did a fine job! But it's not, it's trying to be a story. In the end, it was a story about nothing with cool moments that left you feeling empty due to how little you cared about anything going on and the nonsensical ways the characters got to where they were.\n\n
But if you want to watch a show for 'so bad it's good' value, go no further! You will find boundless enjoyment from Kabaneri! Come one come all, laugh at our protagonist's constant yelling of names! Cry at the beautiful parallels in timing to Thomas the Tank Engine! Shout at your screen from the characters' senseless decisions! It's a good time.\n\n
Review over.

What can I say, Koutetsujou, you started out with an interesting and engaging plot but then you took a left turn into a reinforced concrete wall. Steampunk zombies would have been great if it wasn't for the useless second half of the series. Strong MC's and supporting characters wasted on pointless plot that in the end got the series nowhere.
Koutetsujou is one of those animes that start off sprinting, and finishes limping at the end didn't even cross the finish line. (Last episode spoilers ahead)
*Spoilers* 
The last episode, what kind of shit  ending was that? Completely sidestepped every problem that came up in allthe other episodes and went for a happy ending where both Mumei and Ikoma survive. After all the death and pointless violence started by Biba, he ends with saving Ikoma in the most convoluted way possible.\n
*End Spoilers*\n

This anime is so underrated and is a lot better than Attack on Titans. Although the two anime have some similar aspects like fighting for their survival, etc., the anime is also very unique and interesting. It isn't corny or cheesy, and unlike a lot of anime that is really similar, Kabaneri is very different in a good way. The art is very clean and i love the characters (their looks/style and personality). Although the ending seemed a bit rushed, there was news that there will be a season 2 in 2018. I cant wait for the character relationship developments, especially with Mumei and Ikoma

Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress starts off in a steam punk world dominated by trains and stations in order for humanity to survive against 'kabane' (basically zombies). Which sounds amazing! Despite this opportunity, it is widely criticized for being an Attack on Titan clone and it can't be denied that the whole production is almost entirely the same (studio WIT, composer Sawano Hiroyuki, Aimer). However I think for the most part they aren't as similar as one should think and in some areas there's a little more maturity, but that doesn't stop WIT from trying to applying its same hit formula to this series disappointingly.


STORY: 5

Somewhere along the way Kabaneri starts to contradict itself in motivations and direction.. possibly due to perhaps over indulgence of a certain antagonist which gave rise to weak tension and climatic moments. Flaws are established and then somehow the story ends up with 10x the amount of flaws that it started with. Particularly in the first quarter of the show, I believe that many viewers were drawn to how the world building was set up, and our introduction to what kabaneri are, and how humanity has adapted with the circumstances. But the truth is that we continue to get bits more about the world and wonder, and even those are never given answers for! The story never truly utilizes these aspects of the world to the extent that it could and seems to prefer only using it as a surface finish. Which in particular leads to problems with establishing the characters in the setting well and gives way to very generic circumstances and plots. Kabaneri tries really hard to push meaning in a overused manner and might have done well had it just maybe stopped trying to give something like it's successor or just give more cool visuals. 


ART: 7

It's got a unique style that was absolutely gorgeous when it needed to be. If the plot wasn't so bad, then the climatic emotional moments drawn would have had immense impact as a viewer. But it so very falls flat because of poor developments. If anything, they should've attempted more fight scenes because they were clearly the highlight of the show. 


The color palette also starts out very dark and edgy but then slowly starts to gradually become the more generic bright tone unfortunately. However, character designs and sets are absolutely fabulous. 


SOUND: 10

This soundtrack is so fucking incredible. Hiroyuki Sawano as the composer, Egoist for the OP, AND CHELLY (EGOIST) AND AIMER FOR THE ED COMPOSED BY HIROYUKI. This is like top, top, talent. How did Kabaneri fall so flat with this genius soundscape is the most puzzling thing. I would not have been able to continue without it. Sadly again, although the mix provides great crucial timing and atmosphere for its scenes, emotionally these are disconnected from the viewer because of poor storyline context.


And to note voice acting, the voice actors performed well in conveying dialogues filled with emotional stresses, especially the main character's. 


CHARACTER: 6

The cast had a lot of potential in the direction they could've been taken in. And perhaps the only one who truly shown out and developed in a substantial manner is Akame who by the end displays a firm grasp of the leadership she wants to pursue. But otherwise, everyone is setup interestingly and likeable (after some rough starts) with unique quirks. Sadly, no one but 3 characters are explored, 2 of which were poorly focused on even then. The main character Ikoma for the most part has some well written unique, dialogue that shows his growth in perspective but for some wrong reasons as well. However, due to lack of time, it could be acceptable. Could. As for the antagonists, his motivations were so poorly framed and constructed that for the most part it didn't justify his grand schemes. The secondary character Mumei also falls to a weirdly approached cliche type of redemption that is unfitting for her defined character. 


ENJOYMENT: 7

It's probably more at like a 6.5 and only because the setting, soundtrack, and character highlight moments drove it up for me. In the end, it is quite a large disappointment only redeemed by how badass some of the characters look. And a cute Ayame x Kurusu reunion moment. (Shit I had lost all hope but that was way too precious). 


*SPOILERS* 

But I'm dying to know, why are male kabaneri's rare?? WHAT AND HOW IS A KABANERI MADE. 

*END SPOILERS*


OVERALL: 6

Without my extreme bias and worship of the soundtrack, I truly think it rates as a 6. Not good enough to be great and dying to watch, but not horribly bad like most of the reviews say. However if you are truly invested in its initial premise, a word of caution because you might end up disappointed. Especially if you like to invest in world building.

Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress.
Kabaneri is an average show with an outstanding setting and world concept of a steampunk fuedal Japan, has fantastic top-notch animation, but suffers from cliche and stupid characters, a cliche and weak plot and an average musical score. Don't watch it.
Unfortunately, I don't think a second season, if it even gets one, will save this show. It needs to cut out the superpowers and cliche moe crap (i.e. Mumei) and develop its characters more.
Its setting is fantastic, but suffers from the same problem as Attack on Titan: trying to be a survival horror series showcasing the vulnerability of humanity against monstrous(literally) odds, but then chucks superpowers at the hero and devolves into a shounen fist-fight.


This show pains me because of its POTENTIAL. We need more original shows and concepts in anime, and I can't stress enough how much I loved the "steampunk samurai" setting: I want to see more. But the characters and story killed it, and while at times the soundtrack did evoke emotions, other times it just didn't fit with the tone of some scenes at all and really detracts from the scene.


The animation, however is top-notch and beautifully done. I will praise one aspect of the characters: the voice actor for Ikoma, the main character. It's nice to see a protagonist with a deeper and more mature voice rather than the usual whiny protagonist, albeit he still has his angst moments as well, but I definitely want to see more of his VA Tasuku Hatanaka: it's great to have more variety in character voice over actors.


All in all, some great concepts, but the end result was less than stellar. Nevertheless, it kept me entertained enough to finish the series to the end in two days, so that's something I guess. 


I know this is bad for me to do, but the only reason it doesn't get a lower score is for its potential and the hope I still cling to for original series to be successful.


I don't dislike Kabaneri because it was bad. I'm disappointed in Kabaneri because it could have been the best.

Well sadly its still a better finale then K project : Return of Kings, but regardless it has it faults. Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress is sub par at best with the most likable character being the deuteragonist mumie and not the annoying cabbage whose instinctual  to sniff out the antagonist with no true suspicion against him (Its only because he wasn't a good enough brother to his own kin that he despises biba off the start). He has more personality then Eren but fails to be better than him(WTF? how is that possible). The action was fine; I wished the series was moreserious though. The only part I did enjoy was Biba and his retribution/revenge plan, he almost reminded me of a non refined version of Makishima; with his responses to murdering and how disposable everyone was to him. Biba like makishima only functioned for his self and his personal agenda, any who opposed died. Its awesome that Biba carries around a Reiterpallasch with human pine resign coated over it, there is speculation his bloodtinge was over 9000 :3 (TRUE THAT MATE) But regardless the anime was no greater than a 6,(It would have been a 10 if : Biba after losing his arm and restoring his embers wrecked that bitch boy cabbage to Lordran and back) .﻿

I was looking forward to watching this anime, but I have to say that I'm extremely disappointed. The first two episodes were good, but then it turned out to be a major disappointed. I thought I would give it a chance and keep on watching it, so I continued watching till episode 9, and I wish I had dropped it way before. 
The plot and story are honestly so stupid and it do not make sense at all. Not to mention the characters, specially the main, Ikoma and  Mumei. Ikoma is the type of character that would just scream stupid nonsense, he is reallyannoying tbh. Mumei on the other hand, was the type of heroine whose strong and can handle everything, but in a very annoying way too. Her personality suddenly changed later too, I have no idea how. You cannot even call it character development. And don't get me started on the other characters..


In short, do NOT watch this anime if you do not want to waste your time.

I watched this series because of hype from my friends by the time it was still airing.. so I decided to step a foot tentatively into this series. I already don't expect something original (well, what is original in this world anyway? Everything is just copy-paste with some improvements or some lacking points..). However, first episode managed to steal my interest with the awesome animation. So I stayed.. hoping the story will get better and become something awesome.. only to be met with disappointment :( 
I feel the story is really poorly written. It is a mesh of Attack on Titan with Guilty Crown inold Japanese industrial setting. Maybe because the studio did AOT before and the scriptwriter is the writer of Guilty Crown.. Although GC boasts good animation but the story is a mess.. and unfortunately that's the fate of Kabaneri as well.


****CONTAIN SPOILERS****

Ikoma really felt like Shu (from GC). He received a power (in this case, being half kabane that gives him superhuman strength) and accompanied with badass chick Mumei.. whom towards the end of the show lost her badass-ness, trapped, became so weak, someone who needs to be saved. Ikoma's design also kinda reminds me of Shu.. both have strange white streaks on their hair.. and had ultra transformation towards the end. 


Kabaneri also borrows ideas from AOT.. being an apocalypse anime, titans turned into kabanes in this anime (except that -- borrowing ideas from GC -- humans can turn into kabanes with infection, just like the apocalypse virus) and instead of Walls, there are stations in Kabaneri where the humans protect themselves inside. 3D manoeuvre gear becomes the steam guns -- which I consider very ineffective. With physics logic it is quite impractical to be used, since steam engines which is used to power the guns are extremely hot and producing hot steams. But well, screw logic, the human bushis in Kabaneri managed to either not burn themselves when using the steam guns, or somehow managed to store steams without it being condensed back into water to propel the bullets. And I don't understand how they design the thing. It seems like the canister is just fastened on a U-shaped frame on the back, without any clasps, safety hooks or whatsoever. It seems like it will drop if you do a flip.. but again, screw logic, even Mumei managed to do somersault without dropping the steam canister =___=


There are a lot of stupid things happening in the anime.. Like the adults who still insist to kick out our two MCs because they are half kabane despite they took action to save the civillian' lives.. the attempt to disconnect the freaking boiler room from the train because Ikoma and Mumei are in it (WTF PEOPLE, IF YOU DETACH THE BOILER FROM THE TRAIN, THERE IS NO STEAM TO POWER THE TRAIN AND IT CANNOT RUN, YOU IDIOTS) then our Biba, another antagonist with screws loose in his head.. so many things I can rant about this anime but oh well, *ehm* I need to continue the review..


****END OF SPOILERS****


The good thing is.. despite using the already tired theme of apocalypse, they introduced something new that people are instantly hooked with.. the steampunk theme. I honestly don't think there's any apocalypse anime with steampunk element yet.. so yeah. Machines, trains, boilers.. this are the interesting elements and thankfully, being utilised well. 


And at least the MC is not some pussy who suddenly have OP power up.. Ikoma is actually pretty badass and he has brain at least, unlike some idiots in this anime. Mumei is actually decent lead as well. She is small but she can fight.. shows her childish side at times but can be badass when needed.. if only Mumei retains her badassness and strength as it was in the beginning of the show and if she's not as gullible and easily swayed emotionally.. a positive development instead of regression.. The side characters are interesting actually.. like Ayame, Kurusu, Takumi, Kajika and others.. if only they have more depth.. if only there's more time to explore them.. The character designs are pretty good in my opinion. Not usual and still have uniqueness, easy-to-spot. 


Kabaneri has some potential to be a great anime but... without solid and non-idiotic story, it cannot and will never be. Although... I did stay to watch until the end because the animation is above average. If you like the semi 2D-3D style like in AOT, you will appreciate Kabaneri. It is something similar, with touch of Japanese style.. To be honest, I like the art style of Kabaneri. The colors are mostly warm - in relation with the fire of the people who keeps burning, the steam machines and the train.. but it turned towards the cooler ambient towards the ending when they no longer on the train. Animations are mostly smooth and consistent, not choppy. The fight scenes are pretty with efficient use of 3D to spice things up and make fights more exciting. Effects like fire sparks, propulsion of the steams and smokes are utilised and blended well without being out of place to boost the mood. The opening video is really well-made. I also like how they used interesting angles, make the best use of composition and direct the anime so it is still enjoyable and not going all over the place. At least it has a start and solved some of the issue (Biba), although it has a lot of holes in between.


Aside from the gorgeous art style, Kabaneri is saved from being total trash thanks to the sound. Opening from EGOIST which gives you goosebumps, beautiful ending from Aimer ft Chelly.. epic soundtrack from Hiroyuki Sawano.. which is so effective in building the mood.


Despite its flaws and shortcomings (and stupidity), I will be lying if I say I don't enjoy Kabaneri at all. It is good to pass time.. but not what you are looking for if you want solid story with good character development.

Okay. Avoiding the spoiler, here`s what I thought after watch complete series.
Back then, I defended the whole series, from Episode 1 until 4. And now how the thing goes?
This what we called "Culture Shock". This is like a spin-off of Attack of Titan, an apology or filler to their ridiculous production time of producing AoT series. Until decided to delay more until it goes 2017.
"Culture Shock" is what we called, different ideology but similar meaning. Titans replaced to Kabane or Zombies. 3D Manuever Gear replaced to Air gun and Trains, and don`t get me wrong since their Idea of bringing train is really great idea.
Themain problem lies when the arc of Biba and that is the falldown of the whole series. I repeat. The whole series. The powerful character, what is it.... Mumei, she strong and more powerful than Ikoma, but she treated like a simple minded idiot character. Ikoma in other hand, simple but reminding Mumei as her sister. Yeah? Brother and Sisters? Is this the best "Kabane Story" they can come up with?


Art design and sound was the only thing that nails it, and reminds me how great the animation was since Attack on Titan was.


Character? Yes you will remember Ikoma and Mumei, but not others. Ikoma as i mention back then, he was "Simple Minded", like what Takumi said so. Mumei in other hand, Strong but Idiot. Other character like Kurisu, a "Simple Minded" also, act as bodyguard Ayame. And lastly, Ayame "Fine Lady". Who controls the key of the Iron Fortress. The main issues of character is because they are skipped and underutilized. Like Ayame knows Archery skills back in Episode 1 only.


Overall. I'm very disappointing to see the most hyped Anime gone rogue.

And from series 24 minutes to 22 minutes in Ep 11 and 12 also remains unknown.


Is it bad to watch? No. Its a Mixed bag ride. This is Michael Bay Japanese version, but extremely weak executions, that begs the question : since when did this happen?


(4 / 10)
